Learn more about treasure hunting [[url:script_link_campaign_searching_ruins]][[tooltip:{{tt:tooltip_campaign_searching_ruins}}]][[col:help_page_link]]here[[/col]][[/tooltip]][[/url]].

Mistress, I have word from the crew that your ship is ready for upgrade. Might I be so bold as to suggest you should upgrade your personal quarters? An illustrious and fearsome figure such as yourself should reap the rewards of success personally.\n\nLearn more about Shipbuilding [[url:script_link_campaign_ship_building]][[tooltip:{{tt:tooltip_campaign_ship_building}}]][[col:help_page_link]]here[[/col]][[/tooltip]][[/url]].

Making a trade agreement with another faction would be a wise way to fence your acquired wealth; an official pact will legitimise your claim to all the treasure you have taken.\n\nLearn more about [[img:icon_trade_agreement]][[/img]]trade agreements [[url:script_link_campaign_trade]][[tooltip:{{tt:tooltip_campaign_trade}}]][[col:help_page_link]]here[[/col]][[/tooltip]][[/url]].

Mistress we have sufficient resources and bodies to upgrade our city. I must advise you to push forward with this expansion.\n\nLearn more about provincial growth [[url:script_link_campaign_growth]][[tooltip:{{tt:tooltip_campaign_growth}}]][[col:help_page_link]]here[[/col]][[/tooltip]][[/url]].

The strength of Krakens' Bane wanes and the Seafather's blessings are weakening! The Sea-God must be in great distress, for the power he gifts Aranessa through Krakens' Bane to be wavering so. The Queen of Tides has sensed the sea is unsettled, that a storm is brewing of such scale that Aranessa herself may struggle to traverse it unscathed. Manann is clearly in pain, and only she can aid the deity and restore power to Krakens' Bane, so she must find the source of this pain and heal it before the seas become a maelstrom. Her first stop is Sartosa, where someone is bound to have some information about the sea’s growing unrest...

Sartosa is a haven for pirates, smugglers, and seafaring lowlifes. Sure enough, one of its denizens spotted something while out on a recent journey on the open seas - a band of Norscan raiders was sighted slaughtering sea creatures. The rumours are that they have declared war upon Manann himself in the name of their Chaos Gods. In response, Aranessa immediately calls on her crew to set sail for Norsca, barking out her orders with bitter, hate-filled words, for only Norscans can draw such ire from their captain. The living members of her crew make the sign of Manann, quietly reciting prayers in anticipation of the fight to come, for Saltspite has already decided the fate of the Northmen responsible for these crimes against the sea, and along with her deckhands she will ensure that they pay for their villainy!

As the final Norscan battle cries are snuffed out, the crew of the Swordfysh call out to their captain to announce that a ship with Empire markings is approaching. Aranessa, known for never letting her guard down, has fired on the Empire before, when they’d approached her unannounced, so they must have important business to risk such a manoeuvre. She allows the ship to approach peacefully, and the commanding officer of the vessel announces himself as an Empire captain by the name of Kolt Ludenhof. He is offering Saltspite a deal – the Empire wish to quell the recent Norscan menace by any means necessary to secure their ocean trading routes. Should Aranessa aid him in this task, she is assured of a generous reward. Aranessa contemplates the offer – she will suffer an alliance with the Empire just as long as there's worthwhile profit to be made.\n\nWith the deal agreed, Ludenhof requests Saltspite head to Norsca to gather more information on what the Norscans are up to. As a down-payment for this task, Aranessa is presented with an incredible gem the size of a fist. Her permanent scowl breaks for a moment and a smile shines across her face with the glow of a new dawn, for her love of jewels is well known. Her scowl quickly returns, however, for now a hunt is about to begin. To Norsca!

After burning several Norscan villages to the ground, Aranessa finds the information she seeks. The raiding parties originated from the Norscan coastal town of Skjold, whose marauders have been targeting islands in the neighbouring seas, slaughtering all marine creatures they encountered and offering them as sacrifices to their Dark Gods. A rage stirs within Aranessa and her heart weeps; such murderous acts against Manann's children cannot be tolerated! Long ago, the Sea-God took her in, raising her as his own daughter through a trio of Sea Nymphs living on one of those very isles.\n\nThe source of the raids must be found, so Aranessa may avenge the slain. With Skjold her next destination, she sends a messenger informing Captain Ludenhof what she has discovered before setting sail.

While on the approach to Skjold, the Swordfysh encountered a small vessel of Marauders that Aranessa’s crew managed to overpower and capture. Before being forced to walk the plank into Promethean-infested waters, one of the captives reveals to Aranessa why the Skjold raiders targeted Manann’s children so relentlessly, alleging that when the chieftain of Skjold heard of the Queen of Tides, he flew into a fit of rage, claiming that she must be his daughter who he’d thought dead and lost. The truth is that he threw Aranessa into the ocean as a baby, believing she would attract the ire of the Dark Gods he was so desperate to impress. She was born bearing the mutations of the sea, which are considered to be a curse sent to draw the ire of the Ruinous Powers. For many Norscans, to accept the gifts of one God is to shun those of another, and so some mutations are punishable by death lest the Dark Gods become jealous. \n\nThe Skjold chieftain mobilised his fleet as soon as he learned that Aranessa was still alive, believing that by murdering as many sea creatures as possible he could prove beyond doubt his rejection of Aranessa before his Gods. She is no longer a baby to be thrown away, however – she is the Queen of Tides, favoured by Manann, who will ensure the Sea-God has his revenge. Saltspite can wait no longer for the Empire’s help - she pledges to slay the pathetic wretch claiming to be her birth-father by her own hand!

Mistress, please push forward. I must advise you capture this whole province in the name of The Drowned.\n\nLearn more about provinces [[url:script_link_campaign_provinces]][[tooltip:{{tt:tooltip_campaign_provinces}}]][[col:help_page_link]]here[[/col]][[/tooltip]][[/url]].

Mistress, the Northmen to the south have left their settlement wide open for you to capture. You should punish these foolish men for underestimating your power, my lady.\n\nLearn more about settlements [[url:script_link_campaign_settlements]][[tooltip:{{tt:tooltip_campaign_settlements}}]][[col:help_page_link]]here[[/col]][[/tooltip]][[/url]].

You have beaten back these uncivilised savages, my lady, but I must insist that you finish the job and kill the remaining curs.\n\nLearn more about factions [[url:script_link_campaign_factions]][[tooltip:{{tt:tooltip_campaign_factions}}]][[col:help_page_link]]here[[/col]][[/tooltip]][[/url]].

Perhaps we should enquire about a possible treaty between our factions?\n\nLearn more about non-aggression pacts [[url:script_link_campaign_non_aggression_pacts]][[tooltip:{{tt:tooltip_campaign_non_aggression_pacts}}]][[col:help_page_link]]here[[/col]][[/tooltip]][[/url]].

As the Lamprey sails along the outlying islands of Northern Yvresse towards Bretonnia, the zombie lookout perched up in the crow's nest, high above the deck, suddenly croaks of a Bretonnian transport galleon moored off one of the smaller islands nearby. He has also spotted its cargo – a large Bretonnian army which has already disembarked onto the land.\n\nFinally, a potential audience! The Bretonnians will hear her sing... and there will be no escape. It is unclear whether they've spotted her eldritch galleon, but it appears that they're already preparing to cast off. Many of the Bretonnian troops are still on the land, however, so Cylostra orders her ship to close in rapidly to intercept them on the shore - once they are within earshot, the show can begin in anger!

Cylostra orders the Lamprey through the Shifting Isles – the ones that are currently visible, at least – ordering her lookouts to keep their rotting eyeballs peeled. At first it seems there's no High Elf naval presence anywhere to be seen - whether the Asur are under the magical protection of the ancient spells shrouding the area, or are simply eluding her by other means, Cylostra does not know.\n\nSuddenly, she spots a ship moored off one of the islands, where large numbers of troops are disembarking. And what's this? Could it be the standard of the Phoenix King she sees? From the look of the ship, it certainly belongs to the High Elf fleet at the very least. There's not time to waste - only time to get ready for the show!

With her cursed ship and damned crew, Madame-Captain Cylostra Direfin perpetually sails the seas, relentlessly searching for an audience to witness her beautiful, deadly songs. Her cursed vocal chords, which enable her to paralyse her victims, become more potent during ocean tempests, yet any ship she encounters at any point on her travels might be a target, dooming seafarers to song-induced paralysis before they are dragged to watery graves by her Undead deckhands.\n\nIn order to be constantly ready for the show, however, Cylostra demands the most prestigious platform from which to sing. The Lamprey – an old and rickety vessel – is her floating stage and requires improvements of the standard she demands. To that end, Cylostra must first fill the ship's coffers with booty.

Cylostra gazes disapprovingly at the Lamprey, a humble galleon of rotten wood and tattered sails – a vessel hardly befitting of a vocal supremo of her standing. Now that she has the funds to do so, Cylostra must enhance the ship and make it worthy of operatic royalty.

Cylostra longs for the fame she enjoyed many decades ago, when she was the favoured court singer of Bretonnian royalty. Many years have passed since those glorious days, and now Cylostra's more sinister reputation - as a terrifying murderous phenomenon of the seas - is known only to those who frequent the ports and coastal cities bordering the Great Ocean, where her terror is spoken of in hushed tones by petrified sailors lucky enough to escape the paralysing clutches of her voice and the murderous grasp of her Unliving crew. For this vainglorious diva, the world is not enough – Cylostra has set her heart on stardom and becoming a household name again. The eyes of the world shall be on her once more, and those who don't know of Madame-Captain Cylostra Direfin soon will!

The Madame-Captain orders her crewmen to sail towards the Bretonnian coastline, for she is certain that the pompous men of chivalry still have good taste. Even if they no longer do, it will not stop her performing for them. Oh yes, the royals of Bretonnia shall love Cylostra more than they ever have before!

The Shifting Isles, ever-deceiving by their very nature, constantly manifest illusions which protect the eastern coast of Ulthuan from unwanted invaders. If Cylostra can somehow find the merchant ship routes used by the High Elves to get to and from the Old World, the way to Lothern and the Phoenix King can be ascertained. These secret routes are rumoured to go right through the Shifting Isles, but Cylostra will not be deterred by the High Elves’ smoke and mirrors!

Those sanctimonious sops in armour, the Bretonnians, 'ave sent an 'eavily-defended convoy of merchant ships our way. Crow reckons they be heading to Araby, and by their sluggishness I'd say they're carrying a goodly haul by those escorts. Let's strike now an' take their riches for ourselves!

So… it would appear that some enterprising fellows from the New World 'ave decided to risk it all against the elements an' of course ourselves, who surely 'ave nothin' left to lose anyway. It's looking pretty likely that Sartosa is their destination. Though they're well protected, taking their cargo as our prize presents an opportunity we daren't pass up.

A convoy of Dark Elf slave ships are heading back to Slaver's Bay, laden with captives raided from Ulthuan's coasts. We should free them... not for altruistic reasons, you understand, but because of their potential as fresh recruits to go on account with us an' join the crew - drowned, raised 'n' bound, they'll be worth more than a cutter full o'gold sovereigns!

Pah! Northmen! Those stinkin' Norscan raiders 'ave been spotted heading back north of Naggaroth frozen following a successful raid on the coasts of the Empire. This particular tribe are known always to take captives for ransom at a later date, so this is an ample opportunity to fill our ratings.

All three verses of the Lost Sea Shanty have been discovered and sung, unleashing the Invocations of Potency hidden within the lyrics. At last, the Star-metal Harpoon now has the power to slay the Merwyrm known as Amanar, but there is one who has been following this ill-gotten quest since the beginning, one whose ship has been stalking yours from afar on the horizon; now you are poised to strike, he steps forward to claim the prize for himself.

You are merely interlopers, for the sea-beast allies itself to the High Elves, who are the mortal enemies of your stalker. Now your use is at an end, he will take the harpoon, kill the beast and revel in the infamy.

That is, of course, only if you let him…

All three verses of the Lost Sea Shanty have been discovered and sung, unleashing the Invocations of Potency hidden within the lyrics. At last, the Star-metal Harpoon now has the power to slay the Merwyrm known as Amanar, but there is one who has been following this ill-gotten quest since the beginning, one whose ship has been stalking yours from afar on the horizon; now you are poised to strike, he steps forward to claim the prize for himself.

You are merely interlopers, for the sea-beast allies itself to the High Elves, who are the mortal enemies of your stalker. Now your use is at an end, he will take the harpoon, kill the beast and revel in the infamy.

That is, of course, only if you let him…

Though you have dealt a significant blow to those mutinous curs, there is still more to do, master. Conquer the remaining settlements of the Vampire Coast and re-establish your... magnanimous rule.\n\nLearn more about provinces [[url:script_link_campaign_provinces]][[tooltip:{{tt:tooltip_campaign_provinces}}]][[col:help_page_link]]here[[/col]][[/tooltip]][[/url]].

Master, those wretched ingrates have occupied the Pox Marsh, territory that rightfully belongs under your command. Let's head there and reclaim your lands.\n\nLearn more about settlements [[url:script_link_campaign_settlements]][[tooltip:{{tt:tooltip_campaign_settlements}}]][[col:help_page_link]]here[[/col]][[/tooltip]][[/url]].

The remnants of those bedraggled sea-dogs still lurks within our reach, master - I implore you to finish them off. Make them walk the plank for their treachery!\n\nLearn more about factions [[url:script_link_campaign_factions]][[tooltip:{{tt:tooltip_campaign_factions}}]][[col:help_page_link]]here[[/col]][[/tooltip]][[/url]].

The entire province has fallen, master, and all within are under your control. I advise you enact a new commandment to cement in the people’s minds that you are their ruler now. \n\nLearn more about commandments [[url:script_link_campaign_commandments]][[tooltip:{{tt:tooltip_campaign_commandments}}]][[col:help_page_link]]here[[/col]][[/tooltip]][[/url]].

Your minion is completely under your control. Let's send them on a mission. And master, I advise you make it a particularly difficult task – only the strong are worthy to serve at your behest.\n\nLearn more about heroic actions [[url:script_link_campaign_hero_actions]][[tooltip:{{tt:tooltip_campaign_hero_actions}}]][[col:help_page_link]]here[[/col]][[/tooltip]][[/url]].

Master, there are creatures we can utilise to further our goals. All we need do is build a suitable lair to summon these minions.\n\nLearn more about [[img:icon_hero]][[/img]]Heroes [[url:script_link_campaign_heroes]][[tooltip:{{tt:tooltip_campaign_heroes}}]][[col:help_page_link]]here[[/col]][[/tooltip]][[/url]].

Your ingenuity has paid off, master, for gifted minions have taken residence in the constructed lair. Now, bend them to your will!\n\nLearn more about [[img:icon_hero]][[/img]]Heroes [[url:script_link_campaign_heroes]][[tooltip:{{tt:tooltip_campaign_heroes}}]][[col:help_page_link]]here[[/col]][[/tooltip]][[/url]].

Master, minions who feel appreciated will always perform better than those who feel spurned. Raise a Lord’s loyalty to maximum and witness the benefits of a fulfilled commander.\n\nLearn more about [[img:icon_loyalty]][[/img]]loyalty [[url:script_link_campaign_vampiric_loyalty]][[tooltip:{{tt:tooltip_campaign_vampiric_loyalty}}]][[col:help_page_link]]here[[/col]][[/tooltip]][[/url]].

Master, I must advise you to make a non-aggression pact with the Vampire Count of Galleon’s Graveyard. With the northern coast's security assured, you can fully focus on the extermination of your oldest foe: the Lizardmen.\n\nLearn more about non-aggression pacts [[url:script_link_campaign_non_aggression_pacts]][[tooltip:{{tt:tooltip_campaign_non_aggression_pacts}}]][[col:help_page_link]]here[[/col]][[/tooltip]][[/url]].

Master, I suggest you establish Pirate Coves at some of your enemies' most profitable settlements. A Pirate Cove can be more profitable in the long run, but you can always take your share of the victor's spoils from battle whilst they are being established. \n\nLearn more about Pirate Coves [[url:script_link_campaign_pirate_coves]][[tooltip:{{tt:tooltip_campaign_pirate_coves}}]][[col:help_page_link]]here[[/col]][[/tooltip]][[/url]].

Master, you are not fulfilling your potential! There are thousands more corpses ready to be raised for your goals - we need only recruit a capable and loyal leader to direct them.\n\nLearn more about raising armies [[url:script_link_campaign_raising_forces]][[tooltip:{{tt:tooltip_campaign_raising_forces}}]][[col:help_page_link]]here[[/col]][[/tooltip]][[/url]].

Master, a band of mortals invades your lands. I advise you show them no mercy and send them to an early grave, and preferably a shallow one, for today's enemies are tomorrow undead fodder.”

Learn more about treasure hunting [[url:script_link_campaign_searching_ruins]][[tooltip:{{tt:tooltip_campaign_searching_ruins}}]][[col:help_page_link]]here[[/col]][[/tooltip]][[/url]].

Master, I have word from the crew that your ship is ready for upgrade. Might I be so bold as to suggest you should upgrade your personal quarters? An illustrious and fearsome figure such as yourself should reap the rewards of success personally.\n\nLearn more about Shipbuilding [[url:script_link_campaign_ship_building]][[tooltip:{{tt:tooltip_campaign_ship_building}}]][[col:help_page_link]]here[[/col]][[/tooltip]][[/url]].

Making a trade agreement with another faction would be a wise way to fence your acquired wealth; an official pact will legitimise your claim to all the treasure you have taken.\n\nLearn more about [[img:icon_trade_agreement]][[/img]]trade agreements [[url:script_link_campaign_trade]][[tooltip:{{tt:tooltip_campaign_trade}}]][[col:help_page_link]]here[[/col]][[/tooltip]][[/url]].

Master we have sufficient resources and bodies to upgrade our city. I must advise you to push forward with this expansion.\n\nLearn more about provincial growth [[url:script_link_campaign_growth]][[tooltip:{{tt:tooltip_campaign_growth}}]][[col:help_page_link]]here[[/col]][[/tooltip]][[/url]].

Luthor Harkon has been looking for a way to restore his connection to the Winds of Magic for decades. Many years ago he disturbed an ancient chamber sealed with some powerful glyphs, which retaliated by draining away his powers. In addition to losing his spellcasting abilities, his mind was shattered into a dozen different facets which left him teetering on the brink of insanity.\n\nWell aware of his mental instabilities, Luthor realises he can no longer risk losing control at a crucial moment, for if a weaker personality were to take over during a fight it could mean the difference between victory and defeat. At the very worst, such a situation could be his very undoing. He decides he needs a capable first mate to take command of his Undead crewmen should he falter at an inconvenient time.

With control over his Undead crew better asserted, Luthor decides to step up his efforts to repair his damaged psyche. He does not know for sure, but thinks it likely that the glyphs which drained his powers and shattered his mind all those years ago were of Slann origin. In a moment of manic realisation, Luthor concludes that the best chance he has to undo his impairments is to find powerful artefacts from the same source.\n\nThe Slann – a powerful species of Lizardmen with an unparalleled mastery over the Sorcerous arts – are known to use many enchanted totems and trinkets of gold to serve their indecipherable purposes. The best chance of finding one is to search the most ancient ruins of the long-abandoned cities and towns of Lustria and beyond, where the Slann are most likely to have left their mark. It may be a long shot, but one that Luthor is desperate enough to take.

Having ordered his Undead crewmen to leave no stone unturned, it seems that the ruins do not contain the artefacts Luthor seeks. His Zombie Deckhands manage to capture a small, reptile-like creature hiding amongst the rubble, which they drag hissing and writhing before him. Gathering himself for a moment, Luthor recognises it as a Skink – a smaller species of Lizardman, typically more mentally agile than others in their cold-blooded ranks. Surely this peon knows how to get his hands on what Luthor seeks?

He demands that the location of any nearby enchanted Slann Gold be revealed, but is brazenly ignored. This lizard-minion obviously does not know who it is dealing with – patience and rationality are not qualities present in any of his fractured personalities. In an instant, Luthor is pressing his pistol against the Skink’s head, muttering lunacies and cocking the hammer. The startled prisoner immediately starts blurts out something about a chest of glyph-embossed medallions buried underneath the very ruins in which they stand. The Skink claims they had previously belonged to the great Mage-Priest Mazdamundi himself, but had been stolen by one of several expeditions that had recently passed through the region.

Luthor turns away to ponder, leaving the Lizardman to his starved Scurvy Dogs. The chest of Slann Gold could be anywhere by now, and finding it will not be simple. Luthor flies into a sudden rage, growling to his crew to prepare for a long campaign of despoilment. He will sack cities near and far in his search, caring not for the wars he might start!

After looting countless settlements and torturing thousands of unfortunate victims, Luthor and his pirate horde come across a shackled slave who claims to have been a former soldier of the Empire. He tells Luthor that he had recently been part of an expeditionary force that found a chest of embossed Slann Gold, but on their way back to camp they were ambushed by a vast Lizardmen army, the largest he had ever seen. The soldier narrowly escaped with his life, but everyone in his troop was slaughtered and the Lizardmen made off back to Lustria with their gold.\n\nClearly this hoard is of great importance to the Lizardmen for them to have brought such a force to take it back – there must be more to this gold than its monetary value alone. Luthor can see his goal clearly now, his mind yearning to be repaired. He needs to gather his minions, return to Lustria, and attack these cold-blooded freaks!

Count Noctilus is well aware of the raw power he can draw from the Galleon’s Graveyard. Having translocated himself and his castle there many years ago, it is a place close to his cold, dead heart, a place where he is able to exert an incredible level of Necromantic control over both the dead and inanimate objects. Indeed, it was in the Galleon’s Graveyard that he forged his floating castle known as the Bloody Reaver from the wreckage of sunken war galleons and set out to dominate the Great Ocean. To help his deathly enterprise, more powerful minions will need to be added to the Undead backbone of Noctilus’ pirate empire. The Maelstrom – the skull-strewn vortex located at the centre of the Galleon’s Graveyard, drawing the dead unto itself like a giant lodestone – must be stoked into a more active state before he can raise them.

Noctilus has always been one to hand-pick the highest-quality Undead servants to bolster his personal crew. One of the most morbid creations the Maelstrom can help to manifest is the Necrofex Colossus – a twisted amalgam of dead bodies fused with the timber and iron of sunken ships to create a monstrous humanoid giant. To wield such unholy power is to be feared in any battle, whether on land or at sea. Noctilus’ rise to power is nigh!

Having put together a crew of unspeakable horrors, this is undoubtedly the time for Count Noctilus to act. But first, to ensure his supremacy over the seas stays unsurpassed, he must ensure that the Galleon’s Graveyard remains out of the reach of rival Necromancers also hoping to harness the boundless power emanating from the Maelstrom. Very few are able to find it without possessing very specific navigational knowledge, but one particular enchanted instrument makes it possible for even a novice to do so – Captain Roth’s Moondial. Captain Roth is a famous seafarer and native of Sartosa, known for being Noctilus’ one-time arch-rival. After one of Noctilus’ midnight raids led to the demise of Roth’s entire family, the anguished captain led a fleet directly to the Galleon’s Graveyard to avenge them, a navigational feat only made possible with his magical moondial. Neither Noctilus or Roth were defeated outright in the immense sea battle that ensued that day, but both suffered extensive casualties. The horrors Roth’s crew witnessed in the Galleon’s Graveyard pushed many of them to desertion following the battle. During the confusion, his moondial was opportunistically stolen, ensuring that the graveyard could never be easily found again.\nAs long as Captain Roth’s Moondial might still be out there, however, Noctilus’ dominance over the seas will always be under threat. The Count senses that other Necromancers must be searching for the moondial, intending to find the Galleon’s Graveyard and use the Maelstrom themselves. There’s no time to waste – he must now begin a campaign of raiding to find it himself, and with any luck he'll uncover the device before they do.

A hefty haul of booty was obtained during Noctilus' raiding campaigns, but Captain Roth’s Moondial continues to elude him. Finally, following a boarding action against an Empire trading vessel daring to cross the Great Ocean, a clue is found – a map, supposedly leading to a treasure chest in which the moondial was last seen.\nNoctilus examines the map closely. He feels like he is looking at one of his own traps, but nothing is going to get in his way. The map might lead him to the moondial, or perhaps to someone who knows where it is. In any case, Noctilus will crush anyone who opposes him!

Master, the Asur still hold large swathes of these lands - we must push forth and take what remains of their territory!\n\nLearn more about provinces [[url:script_link_campaign_provinces]][[tooltip:{{tt:tooltip_campaign_provinces}}]][[col:help_page_link]]here[[/col]][[/tooltip]][[/url]].

The Asur of Caledor will be a persistent annoyance if they are not dealt with swiftly. We should strike them while they are still preparing!\n\nLearn more about settlements [[url:script_link_campaign_settlements]][[tooltip:{{tt:tooltip_campaign_settlements}}]][[col:help_page_link]]here[[/col]][[/tooltip]][[/url]].

The God of Tricks has left his treasures within, but unless you’re an Elf, do not worry that trespassing here is a sin.
To the north of the pirate’s isle lies a bejewelled city whose wonder has the power to enchant and beguile.
Following this verse does not make you a pawn - simply look south to the highest point of dawn.
To find what you seek, do not be so meek, for the guardian stands proud; so tall that its head is in the clouds.
Sleep is not required, for in the north there is something harsh amidst the treasure of the marsh.

Within the shadow of a moon’s touch and by the creeping boughs lies a reef in which your prize awaits.
At the mouth of the forgotten Vitae River, under the shine of Amenemhetum’s sentinel, the water fogs with blood.
At the foot of the burning mount, in a trench withered of life, an auric skull awaits its seeker.
A riddle to find a beast of riddles, walk the steps of the scavenger’s roost that stands within the snake’s trail.
Within sight of Settra’s throne, fed by an ashen river, the scarlet oasis awaits its next victim.
Islands three of stars and sun. Tempests and treasures to be found within the triplets’ grasp.
The raging twins roar and spit. Embrace their rage, ignore their anger, and step between the fury to find the reward you seek.
Pierce the green mists, behold what arises from the canopy, and an ancient one shall greet you with a ruby eye.
Beware the grave, for it calls to us all. But where will you rest in peace? In soil, or in the depths summoned by the Maelstrom’s call?
Halflings would surely freeze if they visited this moot, but in the south lies a fire undimmed by ice.
Come to a coast ravaged by talon and claw, but do not miss the point for it traces the way to a monolithic secret.
Close to the mount of spiders, find what is lost, for the highlands beyond the plateau hold what you seek.
The desert sands hold only death, but legends also speak of eternal life should you seek the season that follows winter and discover the scarlet pools.
To walk though this passage is to stride through history; a place where Orcs, gods and emperors have fought, and the fire of their bloody rage is encased in darkness.
To find this treasure you must wander under the eyes of watchers that guard the ways, and into a kingdom where the seasons rule.

Luthor Harkon has been looking for a way to restore his connection to the Winds of Magic for decades. Many years ago he disturbed an ancient chamber sealed with some powerful glyphs, which retaliated by draining away his powers. In addition to losing his spellcasting abilities, his mind was shattered into a dozen different facets which left him teetering on the brink of insanity.\n\nWell aware of his mental instabilities, Luthor realises he can no longer risk losing control at a crucial moment, for if a weaker personality were to take over during a fight it could mean the difference between victory and defeat. At the very worst, such a situation could be his very undoing. He decides he needs a capable first mate to take command of his Undead crewmen should he falter at an inconvenient time.

With control over his Undead crew better asserted, Luthor decides to step up his efforts to repair his damaged psyche. He does not know for sure, but thinks it likely that the glyphs which drained his powers and shattered his mind all those years ago were of Slann origin. In a moment of manic realisation, Luthor concludes that the best chance he has to undo his impairments is to find powerful artefacts from the same source.\n\nThe Slann – a powerful species of Lizardmen with an unparalleled mastery over the Sorcerous arts – are known to use many enchanted totems and trinkets of gold to serve their indecipherable purposes. The best chance of finding one is to search the most ancient ruins of the long-abandoned cities and towns of Lustria and beyond, where the Slann are most likely to have left their mark. It may be a long shot, but one that Luthor is desperate enough to take.

Having ordered his Undead crewmen to leave no stone unturned, it seems that the ruins do not contain the artefacts Luthor seeks. His Zombie Deckhands manage to capture a small, reptile-like creature hiding amongst the rubble, which they drag hissing and writhing before him. Gathering himself for a moment, Luthor recognises it as a Skink – a smaller species of Lizardman, typically more mentally agile than others in their cold-blooded ranks. Surely this peon knows how to get his hands on what Luthor seeks?

He demands that the location of any nearby enchanted Slann Gold be revealed, but is brazenly ignored. This lizard-minion obviously does not know who it is dealing with – patience and rationality are not qualities present in any of his fractured personalities. In an instant, Luthor is pressing his pistol against the Skink’s head, muttering lunacies and cocking the hammer. The startled prisoner immediately starts blurts out something about a chest of glyph-embossed medallions buried underneath the very ruins in which they stand. The Skink claims they had previously belonged to the great Mage-Priest Mazdamundi himself, but had been stolen by one of several expeditions that had recently passed through the region.

Luthor turns away to ponder, leaving the Lizardman to his starved Scurvy Dogs. The chest of Slann Gold could be anywhere by now, and finding it will not be simple. Luthor flies into a sudden rage, growling to his crew to prepare for a long campaign of despoilment. He will sack cities near and far in his search, caring not for the wars he might start!

After looting countless settlements and torturing thousands of unfortunate victims, Luthor and his pirate horde come across a shackled slave who claims to have been a former soldier of the Empire. He tells Luthor that he had recently been part of an expeditionary force that found a chest of embossed Slann Gold, but on their way back to camp they were ambushed by a vast Lizardmen army, the largest he had ever seen. The soldier narrowly escaped with his life, but everyone in his troop was slaughtered and the Lizardmen made off back to Lustria with their gold.\n\nClearly this hoard is of great importance to the Lizardmen for them to have brought such a force to take it back – there must be more to this gold than its monetary value alone. Luthor can see his goal clearly now, his mind yearning to be repaired. He needs to gather his minions, return to Lustria, and attack these cold-blooded freaks!

Count Noctilus is well aware of the raw power he can draw from the Galleon’s Graveyard. Having translocated himself and his castle there many years ago, it is a place close to his cold, dead heart, a place where he is able to exert an incredible level of Necromantic control over both the dead and inanimate objects. Indeed, it was in the Galleon’s Graveyard that he forged his floating castle known as the Bloody Reaver from the wreckage of sunken war galleons and set out to dominate the Great Ocean. To help his deathly enterprise, more powerful minions will need to be added to the Undead backbone of Noctilus’ pirate empire. The Maelstrom – the skull-strewn vortex located at the centre of the Galleon’s Graveyard, drawing the dead unto itself like a giant lodestone – must be stoked into a more active state before he can raise them.

Noctilus has always been one to hand-pick the highest-quality Undead servants to bolster his personal crew. One of the most morbid creations the Maelstrom can help to manifest is the Necrofex Colossus – a twisted amalgam of dead bodies fused with the timber and iron of sunken ships to create a monstrous humanoid giant. To wield such unholy power is to be feared in any battle, whether on land or at sea. Noctilus’ rise to power is nigh!

Having put together a crew of unspeakable horrors, this is undoubtedly the time for Count Noctilus to act. But first, to ensure his supremacy over the seas stays unsurpassed, he must ensure that the Galleon’s Graveyard remains out of the reach of rival Necromancers also hoping to harness the boundless power emanating from the Maelstrom. Very few are able to find it without possessing very specific navigational knowledge, but one particular enchanted instrument makes it possible for even a novice to do so – Captain Roth’s Moondial. Captain Roth is a famous seafarer and native of Sartosa, known for being Noctilus’ one-time arch-rival. After one of Noctilus’ midnight raids led to the demise of Roth’s entire family, the anguished captain led a fleet directly to the Galleon’s Graveyard to avenge them, a navigational feat only made possible with his magical moondial. Neither Noctilus or Roth were defeated outright in the immense sea battle that ensued that day, but both suffered extensive casualties. The horrors Roth’s crew witnessed in the Galleon’s Graveyard pushed many of them to desertion following the battle. During the confusion, his moondial was opportunistically stolen, ensuring that the graveyard could never be easily found again.\nAs long as Captain Roth’s Moondial might still be out there, however, Noctilus’ dominance over the seas will always be under threat. The Count senses that other Necromancers must be searching for the moondial, intending to find the Galleon’s Graveyard and use the Maelstrom themselves. There’s no time to waste – he must now begin a campaign of raiding to find it himself, and with any luck he'll uncover the device before they do.

A hefty haul of booty was obtained during Noctilus' raiding campaigns, but Captain Roth’s Moondial continues to elude him. Finally, following a boarding action against an Empire trading vessel daring to cross the Great Ocean, a clue is found – a map, supposedly leading to a treasure chest in which the moondial was last seen.\nNoctilus examines the map closely. He feels like he is looking at one of his own traps, but nothing is going to get in his way. The map might lead him to the moondial, or perhaps to someone who knows where it is. In any case, Noctilus will crush anyone who opposes him!

A self-obsessed singer needs a doting audience, and Cylostra is technically still well overdue for a high-profile performance before the High Elves of Ulthuan. Many years ago, when the Lamprey succumbed to a storm in the Eastern Straits of the Great Ocean, before Cylostra’s transformation, she was on an important diplomatic voyage to sing before the Phoenix King. A treaty of great import was reliant on his pleasure in her performance, for the Elves believe good art – music in particular – to be as valuable as gems and gold. It was an important engagement, so surely the High Elves will still be waiting for her? Cylostra decided to head towards the southern end of the Shifting Isles, where the High Elves' Old World shipping lanes are located, following them directly into the great Elven port of Lothern and, hopefully, to the Phoenix King himself... \n\nCylostra orders the Lamprey through the Shifting Isles – the ones that are currently visible, at least – ordering her lookouts to keep their rotting eyeballs peeled. At first it seems there's no High Elf naval presence anywhere to be seen - whether the Asur are under the magical protection of the ancient spells shrouding the area, or are simply eluding her by other means, Cylostra does not know. Suddenly, she spots a ship moored off one of the islands, where large numbers of troops are disembarking. And what's this? Could it be the standard of the Phoenix King she sees? From the look of the ship, it certainly belongs to the High Elf fleet at the very least. There's not time to waste - only time to get ready for the show!

A strong start, Krakenlord, but do not underestimate the Lizardmen - they are hardy an' fierce. We should capture this whole territory an' allow them no respite.\n\nLearn more about provinces [[url:script_link_campaign_provinces]][[tooltip:{{tt:tooltip_campaign_provinces}}]][[col:help_page_link]]here[[/col]][[/tooltip]][[/url]].

This was once a great Skaven burrow; those perfidious ratmen’s primary concern is hindering the greater races, so there is likely to be a great stash of scrolls. Though the altar looks dilapidated, take care, Fellheart, for the Skaven are not known for making their presence known until it is too late.\n\nLearn more about ritual resource sites [[url:script_link_campaign_ritual_resource_sites]][[tooltip:{{tt:tooltip_campaign_ritual_resource_sites}}]][[col:help_page_link]]here[[/col]][[/tooltip]][[/url]].

The Lizardmen roam these lands - lands that should rightfully be ruled by you, my lord. Take their settlement and secure your foothold on mainland Lustria!\n\nLearn more about settlements [[url:script_link_campaign_settlements]][[tooltip:{{tt:tooltip_campaign_settlements}}]][[col:help_page_link]]here[[/col]][[/tooltip]][[/url]].

Good, but the task is not yet complete; erect a shrine to Hekarti to draw her eyes on us, so the Mistress of Magic may reveal further scrolls.\n\nLearn more about buildings [[url:script_link_campaign_buildings]][[tooltip:{{tt:tooltip_campaign_buildings}}]][[col:help_page_link]]here[[/col]][[/tooltip]][[/url]].

My preparations are almost complete, but it’s now clear that other races intend to usurp the Vortex. We must be first! Get me more scrolls so I can enact the ritual!\n\nLearn more about ritual currency [[url:script_link_campaign_ritual_currency]][[tooltip:{{tt:tooltip_campaign_ritual_currency}}]][[col:help_page_link]]here[[/col]][[/tooltip]][[/url]].

The Lizardmen here are outnumbered and without purpose, their Great Plan has amounted to nothing. It is time for them to follow the Old Ones and leave this world.\n\nLearn more about factions [[url:script_link_campaign_factions]][[tooltip:{{tt:tooltip_campaign_factions}}]][[col:help_page_link]]here[[/col]][[/tooltip]][[/url]].

The entire province is subjugated, Lokhir. Your words are absolute - issue a commandment and your Corsairs will see them carried out.\n\nLearn more about commandments [[url:script_link_campaign_commandments]][[tooltip:{{tt:tooltip_campaign_commandments}}]][[col:help_page_link]]here[[/col]][[/tooltip]][[/url]].

It is time, Lokhir to enact the Ritual of the Tortured Oracle!\n\nLearn more about rituals [[url:script_link_campaign_rituals]][[tooltip:{{tt:tooltip_campaign_rituals}}]][[col:help_page_link]]here[[/col]][[/tooltip]][[/url]].

Your thrall awaits their first mission. Let's make it challenging… \n\nLearn more about heroic actions [[url:script_link_campaign_hero_actions]][[tooltip:{{tt:tooltip_campaign_hero_actions}}]][[col:help_page_link]]here[[/col]][[/tooltip]][[/url]].

There are agents and factors who wish to petition your favour. Ensure they have a place to assemble so we can weed out potential vassals... and traitors.\n\nLearn more about [[img:icon_hero]][[/img]]Heroes [[url:script_link_campaign_heroes]][[tooltip:{{tt:tooltip_campaign_heroes}}]][[col:help_page_link]]here[[/col]][[/tooltip]][[/url]].

We have the location where the vassals may congregate. Now it is time to summon these ‘heroes’ to serve.\n\nLearn more about [[img:icon_hero]][[/img]]Heroes [[url:script_link_campaign_heroes]][[tooltip:{{tt:tooltip_campaign_heroes}}]][[col:help_page_link]]here[[/col]][[/tooltip]][[/url]].

My lord, I must beseech you to seek allies. Though the Tomb Kings cannot be trusted in the long term, a temporary agreement would be beneficial for all parties. Sign a non-aggression pact with Khalida’s Court of Lybaras, which should allow you sufficient time to prepare for the war that is sure to come.\n\nLearn more about non-aggression pacts [[url:script_link_campaign_non_aggression_pacts]][[tooltip:{{tt:tooltip_campaign_non_aggression_pacts}}]][[col:help_page_link]]here[[/col]][[/tooltip]][[/url]].

You cannot do this alone, Fellheart. Though you command the most elite Corsairs to ever sail the seas, you are outnumbered. However, there are others who would rally to your call and follow orders. You need only call upon them.\n\nLearn more about raising armies [[url:script_link_campaign_raising_forces]][[tooltip:{{tt:tooltip_campaign_raising_forces}}]][[col:help_page_link]]here[[/col]][[/tooltip]][[/url]].

A warband of Greenskins have appeared in your lands Lokhir; the longer you allow them to live, the more likely they are to hinder your progress in this great race. Exterminate the creatures with all the prejudice they deserve!\n\nLearn more about rogue armies [[url:script_link_campaign_rogue_armies]][[tooltip:{{tt:tooltip_campaign_rogue_armies}}]][[col:help_page_link]]here[[/col]][[/tooltip]][[/url]].

The ritual is all but prepared, Krakenlord, but first you must furnish me with the scrolls of Hekarti to power such a rite. I suggest searching the ruins.\n\nLearn more about treasure hunting [[url:script_link_campaign_searching_ruins]][[tooltip:{{tt:tooltip_campaign_searching_ruins}}]][[col:help_page_link]]here[[/col]][[/tooltip]][[/url]].

Though you are known for taking by force, fostering trade can be just a beneficial for the coffers. Encourage the Tomb Kings to share the gold for which they have no use.\n\nLearn more about [[img:icon_trade_agreement]][[/img]]trade agreements [[url:script_link_campaign_trade]][[tooltip:{{tt:tooltip_campaign_trade}}]][[col:help_page_link]]here[[/col]][[/tooltip]][[/url]].

Momentum gathers. Druchii flock to your banners. Betrayal is inevitable if you do not rule with a strong hand; for now, take advantage of your growing following and expand your settlements.\n\nLearn more about provincial growth [[url:script_link_campaign_growth]][[tooltip:{{tt:tooltip_campaign_growth}}]][[col:help_page_link]]here[[/col]][[/tooltip]][[/url]].

Lokhir’s famed dual swords, the Red Blades, have slain many foes for the Corsair King. However, the power imbued within them, drawn from the Indan God Gilgadresh’s statue, is failing. The only way to restore the blades to their former state is to regularly gorge them with blood – but not just any blood, for only the blood of the most anguished victims will sate them.\n\nFor Lokhir, Karond Kar is an obvious target of conquest for these ends – also known as ‘Slaver’s Gate’, it is home to many slaves living the final minutes, hours, or days of their pitiful lives as miserable drudges. The readily-available blood of these thralls, downtrodden then sacrificed, shall be more than enough to slake the Red Blades once again!

The strength of Krakens' Bane wanes and the Seafather's blessings are weakening! The Sea-God must be in great distress, for the power he gifts Aranessa through Krakens' Bane to be wavering so. The Queen of Tides has sensed the sea is unsettled, that a storm is brewing of such scale that Aranessa herself may struggle to traverse it unscathed. Manann is clearly in pain, and only she can aid the deity and restore power to Krakens' Bane, so she must find the source of this pain and heal it before the seas become a maelstrom. Her first stop is Sartosa, where someone is bound to have some information about the sea’s growing unrest...

Sartosa is a haven for pirates, smugglers, and seafaring lowlifes. Sure enough, one of its denizens spotted something while out on a recent journey on the open seas - a band of Norscan raiders was sighted slaughtering sea creatures. The rumours are that they have declared war upon Manann himself in the name of their Chaos Gods. In response, Aranessa immediately calls on her crew to set sail for Norsca, barking out her orders with bitter, hate-filled words, for only Norscans can draw such ire from their captain. The living members of her crew make the sign of Manann, quietly reciting prayers in anticipation of the fight to come, for Saltspite has already decided the fate of the Northmen responsible for these crimes against the sea, and along with her deckhands she will ensure that they pay for their villainy!

As the final Norscan battle cries are snuffed out, the crew of the Swordfysh call out to their captain to announce that a ship with Empire markings is approaching. Aranessa, known for never letting her guard down, has fired on the Empire before, when they’d approached her unannounced, so they must have important business to risk such a manoeuvre. She allows the ship to approach peacefully, and the commanding officer of the vessel announces himself as an Empire captain by the name of Kolt Ludenhof. He is offering Saltspite a deal – the Empire wish to quell the recent Norscan menace by any means necessary to secure their ocean trading routes. Should Aranessa aid him in this task, she is assured of a generous reward. Aranessa contemplates the offer – she will suffer an alliance with the Empire just as long as there's worthwhile profit to be made.\n\nWith the deal agreed, Ludenhof requests Saltspite head to Norsca to gather more information on what the Norscans are up to. As a down-payment for this task, Aranessa is presented with an incredible gem the size of a fist. Her permanent scowl breaks for a moment and a smile shines across her face with the glow of a new dawn, for her love of jewels is well known. Her scowl quickly returns, however, for now a hunt is about to begin. To Norsca!

After burning several Norscan villages to the ground, Aranessa finds the information she seeks. The raiding parties originated from the Norscan coastal town of Skjold, whose marauders have been targeting islands in the neighbouring seas, slaughtering all marine creatures they encountered and offering them as sacrifices to their Dark Gods. A rage stirs within Aranessa and her heart weeps; such murderous acts against Manann's children cannot be tolerated! Long ago, the Sea-God took her in, raising her as his own daughter through a trio of Sea Nymphs living on one of those very isles.\n\nThe source of the raids must be found, so Aranessa may avenge the slain. With Skjold her next destination, she sends a messenger informing Captain Ludenhof what she has discovered before setting sail.

While on the approach to Skjold, the Swordfysh encountered a small vessel of Marauders that Aranessa’s crew managed to overpower and capture. Before being forced to walk the plank into Promethean-infested waters, one of the captives reveals to Aranessa why the Skjold raiders targeted Manann’s children so relentlessly, alleging that when the chieftain of Skjold heard of the Queen of Tides, he flew into a fit of rage, claiming that she must be his daughter who he’d thought dead and lost. The truth is that he threw Aranessa into the ocean as a baby, believing she would attract the ire of the Dark Gods he was so desperate to impress. She was born bearing the mutations of the sea, which are considered to be a curse sent to draw the ire of the Ruinous Powers. For many Norscans, to accept the gifts of one God is to shun those of another, and so some mutations are punishable by death lest the Dark Gods become jealous. \n\nThe Skjold chieftain mobilised his fleet as soon as he learned that Aranessa was still alive, believing that by murdering as many sea creatures as possible he could prove beyond doubt his rejection of Aranessa before his Gods. She is no longer a baby to be thrown away, however – she is the Queen of Tides, favoured by Manann, who will ensure the Sea-God has his revenge. Saltspite can wait no longer for the Empire’s help - she pledges to slay the pathetic wretch claiming to be her birth-father by her own hand!

As the Lamprey sails along the outlying islands of Northern Yvresse towards Bretonnia, the zombie lookout perched up in the crow's nest, high above the deck, suddenly croaks of a Bretonnian transport galleon moored off one of the smaller islands nearby. He has also spotted its cargo – a large Bretonnian army which has already disembarked onto the land.\n\nFinally, a potential audience! The Bretonnians will hear her sing... and there will be no escape. It is unclear whether they've spotted her eldritch galleon, but it appears that they're already preparing to cast off. Many of the Bretonnian troops are still on the land, however, so Cylostra orders her ship to close in rapidly to intercept them on the shore - once they are within earshot, the show can begin in anger!

Cylostra orders the Lamprey through the Shifting Isles – the ones that are currently visible, at least – ordering her lookouts to keep their rotting eyeballs peeled. At first it seems there's no High Elf naval presence anywhere to be seen - whether the Asur are under the magical protection of the ancient spells shrouding the area, or are simply eluding her by other means, Cylostra does not know.\n\nSuddenly, she spots a ship moored off one of the islands, where large numbers of troops are disembarking. And what's this? Could it be the standard of the Phoenix King she sees? From the look of the ship, it certainly belongs to the High Elf fleet at the very least. There's not time to waste - only time to get ready for the show!

With her cursed ship and damned crew, Madame-Captain Cylostra Direfin perpetually sails the seas, relentlessly searching for an audience to witness her beautiful, deadly songs. Her cursed vocal chords, which enable her to paralyse her victims, become more potent during ocean tempests, yet any ship she encounters at any point on her travels might be a target, dooming seafarers to song-induced paralysis before they are dragged to watery graves by her Undead deckhands.\n\nIn order to be constantly ready for the show, however, Cylostra demands the most prestigious platform from which to sing. The Lamprey – an old and rickety vessel – is her floating stage and requires improvements of the standard she demands. To that end, Cylostra must first fill the ship's coffers with booty.

Cylostra gazes disapprovingly at the Lamprey, a humble galleon of rotten wood and tattered sails – a vessel hardly befitting of a vocal supremo of her standing. Now that she has the funds to do so, Cylostra must enhance the ship and make it worthy of operatic royalty.

Cylostra longs for the fame she enjoyed many decades ago, when she was the favoured court singer of Bretonnian royalty. Many years have passed since those glorious days, and now Cylostra's more sinister reputation - as a terrifying murderous phenomenon of the seas - is known only to those who frequent the ports and coastal cities bordering the Great Ocean, where her terror is spoken of in hushed tones by petrified sailors lucky enough to escape the paralysing clutches of her voice and the murderous grasp of her Unliving crew. For this vainglorious diva, the world is not enough – Cylostra has set her heart on stardom and becoming a household name again. The eyes of the world shall be on her once more, and those who don't know of Madame-Captain Cylostra Direfin soon will!

The Madame-Captain orders her crewmen to sail towards the Bretonnian coastline, for she is certain that the pompous men of chivalry still have good taste. Even if they no longer do, it will not stop her performing for them. Oh yes, the royals of Bretonnia shall love Cylostra more than they ever have before!

The Shifting Isles, ever-deceiving by their very nature, constantly manifest illusions which protect the eastern coast of Ulthuan from unwanted invaders. If Cylostra can somehow find the merchant ship routes used by the High Elves to get to and from the Old World, the way to Lothern and the Phoenix King can be ascertained. These secret routes are rumoured to go right through the Shifting Isles, but Cylostra will not be deterred by the High Elves’ smoke and mirrors!

A self-obsessed singer needs a doting audience, and Cylostra is technically still well overdue for a high-profile performance before the High Elves of Ulthuan. Many years ago, when the Lamprey succumbed to a storm in the Eastern Straits of the Great Ocean, before Cylostra’s transformation, she was on an important diplomatic voyage to sing before the Phoenix King. A treaty of great import was reliant on his pleasure in her performance, for the Elves believe good art – music in particular – to be as valuable as gems and gold. It was an important engagement, so surely the High Elves will still be waiting for her? Cylostra decided to head towards the southern end of the Shifting Isles, where the High Elves' Old World shipping lanes are located, following them directly into the great Elven port of Lothern and, hopefully, to the Phoenix King himself... \n\nCylostra orders the Lamprey through the Shifting Isles – the ones that are currently visible, at least – ordering her lookouts to keep their rotting eyeballs peeled. At first it seems there's no High Elf naval presence anywhere to be seen - whether the Asur are under the magical protection of the ancient spells shrouding the area, or are simply eluding her by other means, Cylostra does not know. Suddenly, she spots a ship moored off one of the islands, where large numbers of troops are disembarking. And what's this? Could it be the standard of the Phoenix King she sees? From the look of the ship, it certainly belongs to the High Elf fleet at the very least. There's not time to waste - only time to get ready for the show!

Lokhir’s famed dual swords, the Red Blades, have slain many foes for the Corsair King. However, the power imbued within them, drawn from the Indan God Gilgadresh’s statue, is failing. The only way to restore the blades to their former state is to regularly gorge them with blood – but not just any blood, for only the blood of the most anguished victims will sate them.\n\nFor Lokhir, Karond Kar is an obvious target of conquest for these ends – also known as ‘Slaver’s Gate’, it is home to many slaves living the final minutes, hours, or days of their pitiful lives as miserable drudges. The readily-available blood of these thralls, downtrodden then sacrificed, shall be more than enough to slake the Red Blades once again!

Lokhir Fellheart's infamous helm has gained a tarnish, and so - some loose-tongued sailors say - does the Krakenlord lose his power! After a mystery that spans the Great Ocean, Fellheart learns that a curse has been placed upon the Helm of the Kraken and the only way to lift it is to slay the caster of this abominable hex. Lokhir returns to his base of operations, from which he can scry his foe's whereabouts.

Lokhir Fellheart is the most infamous of all the Black Arks' masters, feared on both continents as a merciless reaver. However, of late the Helm of the Kraken, which some reckon is the source of his fearful reputation, has begun to tarnish. Fellheart swats aside such notions, and to prove that he and he alone is the master of his destiny, sets out on his greatest voyage of wanton piracy. But before he begins, he must ensure he's got a full complement of crew.

Now that Lokhir Fellheart's Black Ark, the Tower of Blessed Dread, has a full complement of blood-thirsty Corsairs, the Krakenlord sets sail in search of prey. Fellheart is not known for his mercy - any foe who gets in his way will be cut down.\n\nAnd yet, the more forcefully he projects his personality, the more his infamous helm is tarnished. Fellheart begins to suspect someone or something has cursed it...

With the slaying done and blood still dripping from their Red Blades, Fellheart orders the Blessed Dread back to sea in search of spoils. Though greater are riches are always desired, it is more important that he looks for the answers that will restore his helm's ethereal gleam. Ill-rumours have reached Lokhir that a verminous curse has been placed upon it but that a counter-hex may be found amidst the sea's hidden treasures...

At last, the answer to the curse has been revealed; found among the recently-plundered loot is a collection of runes that look like Warpstone tokens. Fellheart's loyal seers believe they will break the curse upon the Helm of the Kraken, but only if the blood of he who initiated the fell spell is spilt. Lokhir must return to his base of operations, from which he can scry his foe's whereabouts.

While in dock at Chupayotl, the Skaven strike! Their sorcerous leader believes they have weakened the Krakenlord, and while he licks his wounds and pride in port, the ratmen will take the spoils and infamy for themselves. But they could not be more wrong... they are not the hunters but the hunted! Fellheart knew the creature that cursed his helm would attempt an incursion here, so his crew lay in wait for the Skaven thieves to board. Afore the day is done, Fellheart shall sluice the decks in ratblood and restore the Helm of the Kraken to its former lustre!

The strength of Krakens' Bane was waning, the Seafather's blessings weakening! The rumours were that a band of Norscan raiders had declared war upon Manann himself in the name of their Chaos Gods, slaughtering innocent creatures of the sea, so Aranessa immediately called upon her crew to set sail for Norsca, swearing that they would pay for their villainy! 

After burning several Norscan villages to the ground, Aranessa found the information she sought, with the help of an Empire captain named Kolt Ludenhof. The raiding parties had originated from the Norscan coastal town of Skjold, whose marauders were targeting islands in the neighbouring seas, slaughtering all marine creatures they encountered and offering them as sacrifices to their Dark Gods. They were under orders from their chieftain, who claimed that the Queen of Tides must be his daughter, who he’d thought dead and lost. The truth is that he threw Aranessa into the ocean as a baby, believing she would attract the ire of the Dark Gods due to the mutations of the sea she bore, which among the Norscans are considered to be a curse. The Skjold chieftain mobilised his fleet as soon as he learned that Aranessa was still alive, believing that by murdering as many sea creatures as possible, he could prove beyond doubt his rejection of Aranessa before the Gods.

Captain Saltspite is no longer a baby to be thrown away, however – she is the Queen of Tides, favoured by Manann, who will ensure the Sea-God has his revenge!

Luthor Harkon had been looking for a way to restore his connection to the Winds of Magic for decades. Many years ago, he disturbed an ancient chamber sealed with some powerful glyphs, resulting in his mind being shattered into a dozen different facets which left him teetering on the brink of insanity. Luthor thought it likely that the glyphs were of Slann origin, concluding that the best chance he had to undo his impairments was to find powerful artefacts from the same source.
\The Slann – a powerful species of Lizardmen with an unparalleled mastery over the Sorcerous arts – are known to use many enchanted totems and trinkets of gold to serve their indecipherable purposes. The best chance of finding one was to search the most ancient ruins of the long-abandoned cities and towns of Lustria and beyond, where the Slann were most likely to have left their mark. After searching countless ruins, Luthor and his pirate horde came across a shackled slave claiming to have been a former soldier of the Empire. He told Luthor that he had recently been part of an expeditionary force that found a chest of embossed Slann Gold, but on their way back to camp they were ambushed by a vast Lizardmen army, the largest he had ever seen. The soldier narrowly escaped with his life, but everyone in his troop was slaughtered and the Lizardmen made off back to Lustria with their gold.

Clearly this hoard is of great importance to the Lizardmen for them to have brought such a force to take it back – there must be more to this gold than its monetary value alone. Luthor can see his goal clearly now, his mind yearning to be repaired. He needs to gather his minions, return to Lustria, and attack these cold-blooded freaks!

Having put together a crew of unspeakable horrors, Count Noctilus decided to ensure his supremacy over the seas stayed unsurpassed, and that the Galleon’s Graveyard remains out of the reach of rival Necromancers also hoping to harness the boundless power emanating from the Maelstrom. Very few can find it without possessing very specific navigational knowledge, but one particular enchanted instrument makes it possible for even a novice to do so – Captain Roth’s Moondial. 

Captain Roth was known for being Noctilus’ one-time arch-rival, after one of Noctilus’ midnight raids led to the demise of Roth’s entire family. This led the anguished captain to lead a fleet directly to the Galleon’s Graveyard, a navigational feat only made possible with his magical moondial. Neither Noctilus or Roth were defeated outright in the immense sea battle that followed, but both suffered extensive casualties. The horrors Roth’s crew witnessed in the Galleon’s Graveyard pushed many of them to desertion following the battle. During the confusion, his moondial was opportunistically stolen, ensuring that the graveyard could never easily be found again.

Much later, following a boarding action against an Empire trading vessel crossing the Great Ocean, a clue is found – a map, supposedly leading to a treasure chest in which the moondial was last seen. Noctilus examines the map closely, feeling like he is looking at one of his own traps, but nothing was going to get in his way. The map might lead him to the moondial, or perhaps to someone who knows where it is. In any case, Noctilus will crush anyone who opposes him!

Afore Valaya’s saddened eyes, the filthy Uzkular of the sea have snatched a righteous victory from true, honest Dawi warriors. The Mother Goddess demands we hunt down this host and send them back to the depths… permanently!

Witnessed by Grungni, a rotten, valueless Undead horde has stolen Dawi treasures from Dawi lands and has dared to take them to Holds beyond our reach, but not beyond our sight - hunt down this host of dead Umgal and avenge this grave offence!

Observed with shock and anger by Grimnir, the dreadful, Unliving creatures of the Vampire Coast have sacked one of our Holds, burning and looting our great fortress. Naturally, this scandalous insult has been recorded in the Dammaz Kron – avenge out noble Dawi kin and strike it from the book!
A crestfallen Grimnir has noticed that the foul Undead ransack and occupy a settlement belonging to ordinary, righteous Dawi folk. The Dammaz Kron has a new grudge - see it is settled at once!

Harkon's mind is split between multiple personalities, all vying for dominance in his head. The only goal they share is the restoration of his psyche; to restore his mind, Harkon must be willing to seek out Lizardmen artefacts and learn of the spell that fractured it.

Lokhir Fellheart's infamous helm has gained a tarnish, and so - some loose-tongued sailors say - does the Krakenlord lose his power! After a mystery that spans the Great Ocean, Fellheart learns that a curse has been placed upon the Helm of the Kraken and the only way to lift it is to slay the caster of this abominable hex. Lokhir returns to his base of operations, from which he can scry his foe's whereabouts.
