However, of late the Helm of the Kraken, which some reckon is the source of his fearful reputation, has begun to tarnish. Fellheart swats aside such notions, and to prove that he and he alone is the master of his destiny, sets out on his greatest voyage of wanton piracy. But before he begins, he must ensure he's got a full complement of crew.

Now that Lokhir Fellheart's Black Ark, the Tower of Blessed Dread, has a full complement of blood-thirsty Corsairs, the Krakenlord sets sail in search of prey. Fellheart is not known for his mercy - any foe who gets in his way will be cut down.\n\nAnd yet, the more forcefully he projects his personality, the more his infamous helm is tarnished. Fellheart begins to suspect someone or something has cursed it...

With the slaying done and blood still dripping from their Red Blades, Fellheart orders the Blessed Dread back to sea in search of spoils. Though greater are riches are always desired, it is more important that he looks for the answers that will restore his helm's ethereal gleam. Ill-rumours have reached Lokhir that a verminous curse has been placed upon it but that a counter-hex may be found amidst the sea's hidden treasures...

At last, the answer to the curse has been revealed; found among the recently-plundered loot is a collection of runes that look like Warpstone tokens. Fellheart's loyal seers believe they will break the curse upon the Helm of the Kraken, but only if the blood of he who initiated the fell spell is spilt. Lokhir must return to his base of operations, from which he can scry his foe's whereabouts.

While in dock at Chupayotl, the Skaven strike! Their sorcerous leader believes they have weakened the Krakenlord, and while he licks his wounds and pride in port, the ratmen will take the spoils and infamy for themselves. But they could not be more wrong... they are not the hunters but the hunted! Fellheart knew the creature that cursed his helm would attempt an incursion here, so his crew lay in wait for the Skaven thieves to board. Afore the day is done, Fellheart shall sluice the decks in ratblood and restore the Helm of the Kraken to its former lustre!

The still-living that dare to plague this realm were foolish enough to send an agent our way. What a specimen - Let's fill our goblets with their blood an' enjoy this fine diplomatic offering, before it gets cold.
This will be interesting - the unloved children of Chaos dare challenge us. Boo hoo! Slay the mewling beast! It’s a kindness really… no, really it is.
Chaos is the enemy of all - we 'ave to kill its agent before their foul taint spreads an' spores... and then we'll *really* be all at sea!

First rule of piracy is never trust a pirate, even one of yer own men... Actually, especially one of yer own men… No matter, ignore my ramblings - we should kill it before it makes a play for our loot!

Khaine commands the Druchii spill blood in 'is name, but 'e never specified whose blood it should be. Let's assist this worshipper of the Bloody-handed God to move closer to their idol by relieving them of their blood!
Dwarfs? Never underestimate 'em - their stature may be small, but the little sods can still cause you a lot of trouble. Kill this one now, before he bites yer kneecaps off!

The men of the Empire are nothing but sycophants to Sigmar, who cares nothing for their worthless lives, yet still they believe 'emselves superior. Let's remind the fools who rules the waves - let's slay their agent, and swiftly!

Greenskins? Don't make me laugh! "Green Tide"? Green puddle more like. Mind you, in large numbers they can be bothersome, so let's murder this one now an' send bits of 'im back to 'em, so they know to try a lot harder next time.

They’re very 'igh 'n' mighty, is Elves, and it's that sort of arrogance that will see them all drowned. Fancy sending a single agent against us instead of a fleet! Let's kill this one in a really int'resting way an' remind 'em back at Ulthuan that they're mortal after all.

The Lizardmen are just a bunch of brainy snakes - they talk of "Great Plans" but all they really do is interfere with ours! Let's kill this 'orrible thing now before it can cause any more 'arm. Now *that's* a great plan!

This solitary Northman acts against us. Naturally, this sort of thing absolutely can't be tolerated - give 'em a yard and they'll take a nautical mile. I say kill this one quickly, and rid ourselves of a problem.
Skaven are little more than vermin. Now, vermin are known for feeding on the dead, but they also drown very easily, so let's sling this one in the drink before they get ideas 'bout the crew, yarrr?
Though we share some goals in common, the Tomb Kings cannot be permitted to interfere with our plans. This agent of theirs cannot be allowed to live. Let's send 'em a Sartosan message - kill it!

Though we’ve all tasted the Blood Kiss, our landlubbin' kin have started to act against us. Presumably, this has somethin' to do with all that 'swarming across the world'-lark rather than good, honest pirating. To make a point, we should slay their agent, making it clear 'oo authored the death.

Oh pull the other one! Would you believe that the creatures of Athel Loren have dared to venture out and challenge us - here, where we command the waves an' tides?! Let's kill this one slowly - it will put off the other cowards from leavin' their little forest.

I think we've made ourselves perfectly clear on this matter - the coasts of the Old World belong to *us* now. We must evict the previous tenants, an' with extreme prejudice, 'cos we don't want repurcussions further down the line, do we?

Why waste all that time an' energy toiling and sweatin' to put a proper pirate base together when you can just relieve someone else of theirs? This place was run by sea dogs like us, so there won't be much in the way of furnishings. Nevertheless, let's take the place and fly our own colours from its walls.

That sorry bunch, the Dark Elves, long to return to their island of Ulthuan, but they the lack resolve of yer 'ardbitten, salty sea dog. To strengthen it - to do them a favour, yer might say - let's take their territory. That'll give 'em the best reason ever to return 'ome.

The troublesome Dwarfs are famed for their wealth, but not their generosity. Clearly, they must be taught to share, like the fractious children they resemble - let's march up there now an' take by force what they will not give up willingly. What say ye?

This settlement of puny men currently belongs to the living, which is something we're gonna 'ave to change, don't yer think? I say we conquer these lands for the furtherment of our own goals - that way lies sense.

They do say that the so-called "Green Tide" has swallowed much of this world. If this be true, we should sail straight on through, full ahead, an' take it back off 'em. This place makes for the perfect starting point, no?

Those arrogant island-dwellers, the Asur, do not consider our Undead horde to be a threat, so say our sources. I say that their ego shall be their undoing! We should launch a major foray into their lands, starting 'ere, today, with this settlement!

Those rubbish sailors, the slimy Lizardmen, 'ave found that their forces 'ere are overstretched. I reckon we must act before they sort their little supply problem - let's take this land from 'em, pushing them deeper and deeper into their jungle retreats.

Those primitive bufoons, the Norscans, build simple settlements which, when ruined, make great foundations for our own, superior ones. Let's reduce this place to rubble and dust - I reckon it'll make a fine outpost yet!
The ever-putrid ratmen hide and skulk in their warrens 'neath the soil. I say we go down there now and flush 'em out - slay the dirty little cowards and build an empire of our own!

The Tomb Kings' once-great desert empire was destroyed by the denizens of the dead. Looks like they didn’t learn their lesson the first time! It's our destiny to take their town an' remind 'em who's superior, whether on land or sea.

I think we can all agree that our Sylvanian cousins have little idea how to manage the... 'needs' of the living. They should learn to think of 'em as pilot fish dependent on the much-larger whale - us - for direction. I say we take this town from 'em and demonstrate the proper way forward.

Bah! This is good, serviceable land but it's being wasted on a few measly tree houses! We should tear them down and build a proper pirate settlement in their place - somewhere to feed alms for our much more deserving cause. What say you?
Those silly Bretonnians, with their legends and stupid shining armour are 'overburdened' with treasure, the poor mites. We should help them out, like, by relieving them of their loot - yay?
I dunno 'bout you but I'm getting sick to the back teeth of those ridiculous Gor herds - they've been a thorn in our side for far too long. 'Tis time we sent 'em to their graves!

Those so-called 'Dark Gods' send their puppets to infect the world with their taint! *Our* world, mind - they've certainly got gumption, I'll give yer that. We should stop the rot - kill the Chaos fiends and keep the seas for the dead, the way 'twas meant to be!

Filthy, stinkin' pirate scum! Not like us, you understand - different, lesser pirates who go against the code 'cos they've got no respect. These traitors need a lesson. Let's kill 'em all - that'll learn 'em!

As you will know, I have very little time for the Druchii - they think themselves the rulers of the sea and masters of all who sail the waves. We know different, however - Manann the Destroyer is god here and we are his 'umble servants like.

Ooo I'm scared! Those Dwarfs are back and apparently they've got scores to settle with us. I say we re-write those entries and make them the last to grace their petty 'Book o'Grudges' - slay every last tiny one of 'em!

Here's a riddle for yer rum-addled bonces: "Who is the greatest enemy, always at yer shoulder?" Time of course - 'e'll lead 'em to Death, which waits for neither man nor beast as we all know. Let's kill 'em and raise them for our ranks and ratings! What say you?

Those Greenskins seek war with all! You gotta hand it to 'em for their tenacity and fightin' spirit though, no? It's almost a shame that we're gonna have to fight 'em and waste every last one of the stupid green gits!
Like you, I've run out of patience with the Asur, who 'ave meddled and been tolerated for far too long. But it ends 'ere - we should ready the fleet for war!

Those cold-blooded Lustrian lizards live an' die by the garbled plans of a long-forgotten race. They're on a hiding to nothing if you ask me - we should make some great plans of our own an' end their miserable servitude, don't yer think?

The Norscans just don't know when they're beaten, the mindless cretins - they're all beard an' no brain. We should kill these particular ones before the Dark Gods start payin' attention and present a united front, yes?

...And still the cowardly, stinkin' rats come at us - fit only for slaughter if the truth be told. They're not much of a foe when it comes down to it are they? Let's slaughter the lot of 'em and be done with it!

You've gotta respect their tenacity, and defeatin' death is a fine thing an' all that, but really the time of the Tomb Kings has long since passed. Now, they're becomin' a nuisance - if we keelhaul one or two and make the others walk the plank, they might get the message that, here on the 'igh seas, we're the ruling power.

Now, we'd be a little naive if we trusted the Vampire Counts, kin or no. Like us pirates, they 'ave the 'abit of betrayal - a hard one to break I'm sure you'll agree. We should vanquish them with haste and bring their armies under our thrall!

Looks like the tides have brought *total* war to our shores. Each day that passes, it's gettin' closer, so we must act now. Bury the Asrai beneath the waves - they'll think twice 'bout leavin' their tree 'ouses after that!

This lily-livered landlubber has a price on their head, which makes 'em something of an attractive target for salty freebooters such as we. Taking this life means we'll be able to claim a generous reward - I'm in, are you?
This place will make a handy base from which to launch all sorts of raids an' actions. If we capture this region and fly our colours 'ere, our pirate brothers-in-arms will support us, I knows it.
This foe is an enemy of all our kind, so we much face 'em in combat and end their run. Think of it as an symbolic and existential battle - one we absolutely cannot afford to lose.
I don't like this lot and I know you don't either, so I'm proposing that we take the fight directly to their door, 'cos a victory here could well be crucial during the wars to come. Are yer with me?
Cor, blimey! This place is ripe for the picking with loot and plunder of all kinds - we should strip it clean in Stromfels' name!

Our enemies think they 'ave the edge, but you an' I know differently - destroying this place of theirs will deal them a heavy blow, make no mistake. Shall we burn it all down and take their trinkets for ourselves?

Ahhh the fancy king of Bretonnia, with 'is - admittedly really quite lovely - suit of armour and 'is pious devotion to that old hag. He thinks 'imself untouchable, yer know! We should rend 'im in two - break the illusion of infallibility and crush the false hope he gives to his people! Let's see 'im talk of destiny with an axe through his 'ead!
column4: No Grave for the Grail Knight

column3: The leader of that stupid herd of Beastmen has reared its particularly 'ungry 'ead once again. I say we lop it orft and watch 'is Gors crumble. I'd like to see 'em try to hunt without 'im - they'll be chargin' 'round in circles, attackin' each other. Free entertainment! Hilarious!

The Dark Gods' lackies swarm around a single leader, who 'imself is obsessed with their grace and favour. This will make our job quite a lot simpler - his death will be the end for these armies of Chaos, so we need to kill this so-called 'Everchosen' in battle, and soon, afore the whole bally lot of 'em show up and we're in bit of a pickle!

Ahh, Luthor Harkon - the ruler of the so-called Vampire Coast, no less. I say we throw 'im all the way down to Stromfels' Chest for the arrogance he's shown, or maybe we send 'im back to The Awakening as just another lifeless corpse to be raised an' bound? Either option works for me!

That prissy, long streak o'seaweed, the ruler of the lanky Dark Elves, is little more than hot air in a barrel. I say we end his reign and the send the Druchii into a panic. Then, we can just pick 'em off like fish in said same barrel. Job done and off to Sartosa for a slap-up feast and grog for all the boys! Yarrr!!

The Dwarf Lord? Do me a favour! He's no more than a petty, bitter librarian consumed by imagined slights an' supposed insults. He's also really, really short, which many of the lads find 'ysterical. We should crush 'im and then write the final entry in 'is blood!

Wow, the emperor 'imself has shown up! That must mean we're doin' something right. Remember he's just a politician, really, 'oo plays at being a warrior. I say we meet 'im in battle so 'e can see first hand that dead pirates cannot be swayed by fancy cloaks an' pretty words.

Oh look - the big boss of the Greenskins has graced us with 'is presence. Like all his kind, he's too stubborn to die and too stupid to retreat in the face of a force like ours! If we can't kill this one, we should bury 'im under an endless zombie horde - either way, he must be dealt with before sundown.

The greatest swordsman in all of Ulthuan 'e may be, but he's still mortal, which we can all agree puts 'im at something of a disadvantage. Shall we introduce the fool to the Gunnery Mob? A dozen or two blunderbusses to the face oughta end this so-called 'sword master'!

As powerful as it is ancient, so they say - the 'ead of all the Lizardmen. I know these snakes, however, and I can tell yer now if we cut off its head, the others will flounder - it'll be the beginnin' of the end for our oldest foes!

The leader of those pathetic Norscans is said to be an accomplished warrior who 'as travelled many a sea. Whether or not that be true - and I suspect it's just flannel as he's just a walking beard really - we should remain cautious. I say we do not take 'im lightly but do take 'is head, yarrr!!

The 'Headtaker' - yep, I know, the arrogance of the thing - is apparently the greatest warrior those cowardly ratmen have to offer. If this be true, then slaying 'im in battle will crush the morale of 'is whole pathetic, ratty race. Couldn’t come soon enough if you ask me!

Ahhh, our old friend the king of self-congratulation - a legend in 'is own lunch hour - is drawn up in front of us with an army. A shame, as we could've 'atched a few lucrative schemes with the Tomb Kings, but instead we're gonna 'ave to kill the lot of 'em. Let's grind 'is army into the dust!

There's nothin' like a good, honest, vengeful rivalry… and this is nothin' like one! Your Unlivin' rival's petty machinations are growing tedious and unimaginative - killin' him in battle will free us from this walkin' annoyance and free up 'is victims to be killed, raised an' bound by us!

They call 'im 'Ariel's Chosen', but when it comes down to it he's little more than a sea dog, but not a good one - a pathetic whelp who'll be easily overcome I'm sure. We should take the battle to 'em before the midwinter pyre robs us of the chance to strike a crushing blow to the Asrai's morale!

Ha! The Bretonnians really are the limit! This foolish 'champion' of sorts believes that their mythical 'Lady' will protect 'em from us! Let's show all those who follow false gods that none can withstand Death's cold embrace! Well, except you of course - you're Unlivin' proof you are.

Oh 'ere we go - more grunting an' nonsense from the beasts o'Chaos. Apparently, this particular 'effer is revered among his stinkin' kind - let's fill it full of lead an' show 'em that pistols trump everything else!

It appears that the Dark Gods are playing their tedious games with yet another simpleton - he believes they actually expect 'im to triumph in battle - against us!! Can you believe the stupidity? I say we kill 'im quickly and put an end to this miserable tale!

Our rivals think they can challenge our power, so we must assert our dominance, lest every scurvy-ridden sea dog on the ocean believes they too can turn on us. Kill their leader in battle, then all will see that it is us an' us alone who rule the waves of this world!

The weasely Druchii believe that it is they who harbour the lords of dread, but we know different like, don't we? Let's prove their misconceptions to be falsehoods - Show 'em the true meaning of dread - slay this leader of theirs in full view of their men!

Normally, I’d be dead bored by this point, but as it turns out, this Dwarf has proven to be quite fierce. Not a problem for a vicious, murdering bunch of pirate scum like us though is it? And killin' him should deal a significant blow to 'is declining race! Let's do it!

This Imperial type has proven popular among both his men an' the Empire's diplomats, such as they are. I reckon that killing 'im and raising his corpse will shake the whole of man's realm to its stupid, cowardly core! Let's spill some blood - pass my bill 'ook, Bernie!

Though 'tis well known that Greenskins are stupid an' pointless, this particular specimen has been developin' somethin' of a reputation among 'is kind as an apt killer. If that be the case, we should kill 'im in battle an' break the morale of 'is boys - they'll crumble in no time, you mark my words!

The High Elves may well be famed for their martial prowess, but no matter how talented they are, sheer numbers will eventually break even the greatest warrior. Prove that to the Asur by saddlin' up the Undead horde and sendin' 'em out.

I like to think of the Lizardmen as a single, giant snake - cut the head orft an' they'll flop about a bit, then breathe no more. If they dare to move against us again, we should kill their leader, sit back and 'ave a few rums whilst they flail and flounder.

This Norscan 'champion', it would appear, has managed - unbelievably - to attract the attention of 'is fickle gods, the Ruinous Powers, an' has gained a name for 'imself as a warrior who does not fear death in any of its guises. He may not fear 'is end, but he would do well to fear what happens afterwards!

The Skaven - as a whole, you understand - are like a ship without a keel: totally spineless. This particular specimen may well have risen through their verminous ranks, but that's of little merit really. I say we kill this ratman - in fact, let's kill 'em all, every last man rat of 'em!

This Tomb King believes it is our equal in battle, but several ages 'ave passed since they were top o'the food chain. We should grace this nauseating bag o'bones with a second an' final death! Shall we kill 'em again? Come on, I want a go...

Our landlocked cousins believe themselves to be superior, even though they just sit there in the dark whilst we're out piratin' for profit! Killing this particular one would serve as a suitable warnin' to others who might want to challenge our dominance. Let's do 'em - as a warning like!

They say that the forests an' woodlands of Athel Loren are burstin' with life - that's even more livin' for us to choke the life out of then, no? We should start by plucking this 'ere weed - sorry, did I say 'weed'? I meant Asrai leader!

Those mortals of Bretonnia ride atop their steeds, thinkin' themselves all unstoppable like. Clearly, they need to be confronted an' filled with musket balls, then raised back into our service. Imagine... our very own elite cavalry brigade! Let's get down to it - there's much killin' to be done!

Ere we go again! They are certainly relentless, those tinkers the Beastmen, but they've been roaming around the land for far too long, unchecked. It's time we met 'em in battle and put an end to their hunt once an' for all - what say ye?

The armies of Chaos march this way, believing themselves chosen by the Dark Gods and tasked with bringin' about the End Times. What a load o'guff, I say - I don't think their Gods 'ave even noticed they're 'ere! Just as well, really, as we're going to kill 'em all now an' put their army under new management!
Rival pirates have gathered a mighty crew, the cheeky bunch o'beggars! Let's greet 'em with a broadside that will shiver their timbers an' rattle their stinkin' Undead bones, yarrrr!!!
So, those lanky, cunning Dark Elves have put together a great army in the hope that we'll cave. Naturally, we won't - let's destroy this cruel host before it can get the upper hand!
Ah, Dwarfs - my favourite, you know. I like 'em boiled with just a little salt an' vinegar! Oh, I do like a good feed - let's go an' pick up dinner!

Manann blesses us this day, me hearties - the Empire have sent an army of their very best living men to face us. Let's not muck about - 'ow about we kill 'em quickly and reinforce our ranks 'n' ratings?
Eads up, lads - 'ere come the Greenskins, literally 'mob-'anded' and 'ungry for… well, their own deaths, I reckon, once our Gunnery Mobs get stuck in and cut 'em in two!

Those 'igh 'n' mighty High Elves mean to meet us in battle with an elite 'ost no less! Well, I dunno 'bout you but I wouldn't wanna disappoint them - let's march forth and give 'em more than a good run for their money!

These Bretonnian fools have promised the impossible – an errantry war against death itself! Slay these ignorant mortals - they're nothin' but a nuisance and it warms me cockles to see 'em screamin' and drownin' in all that armour!

The Beastmen have dared to enter territory that everybody knows belongs to us - the little scamps! We can't let a transgression like that go unpunished now, can we? Let's kill all of 'em and then I suppose we'll 'ave to find a use for their corpses...

Like clockwork, the armies of Chaos 'ave arrived, seeking to destroy all we've built up o'er the years. Yep - I agree, it is unacceptable behaviour. We should meet them in battle and see to their immediate destruction.

A band of rival pirates 'ave invaded our land and are looking to take our loot for 'emselves! Cheek like this simply cannot stand! We need to block off their retreat and finish them in battle once and for all!

Dark Elves 'ave marched into lands that all 'ere know are rightly ours. We can't tolerate this sort of thing - give 'em an inch an' they take a nautical mile. Let's load up the cannons with buckshot an' fill 'em full o'holes!
The Dwarfs have invaded our land - these stunted fools come seeking our territory but all they'll find is their own doom! Yarrr! March against 'em - turn 'em into steaks for our tea!
The Empire might claim these lands as their own, but the fools don't realise that we acquired this prize fair an' square, like, and we will not relinquish it without a fight. So, let's go to battle!
They're nothin' if not persistent, those dirty little Greenskins. They've come here, to *our* land and seek battle. I saw we give 'em what they want an' preferably more than they can 'andle!

Those highfalutin, lanky landlubber, the High Elves, 'ave sent an army to our lands, bless their cotton socks. Apparently, they've got destruction on their minds, which must be awful for 'em, the poor mites. Let's relieve 'em of their lives, shall we? Shall we raise our dead and prepare for a scrap?

Those snaky Lizardmen are invading! Trouble is, at one point all this belonged to 'em, so they've got the arse 'bout our presence 'ere. I reckon that we need to push 'em back before they can undo all our progress in these parts!
Those dirty Norscan dogs 'ave invaded our lands - *our* lands, the cheeky swines. Let's seek 'em out and send 'em back to the frozen north from whence they came!

You've really gotta watch 'em like a hawk - those tenacious ratmen have burrowed their way into our lands. Let's take the breath from their bodies and break this host into lots o'little rat pieces! Yarrr!!

The stinkin', untrustworthy Tomb Kings have gathered together their armies of old and moved 'em against us. Seems a bit unfair - after all, we just want loot an' power - that's not too much to ask it is? Let's meet 'em in battle an' ensure they do not march again.

The sneaky, but nevertheless namby-pamby milksops, the Vampire Counts, have raised their own Undead force and march into our lands. Clearly this is more than a bit naughty - it is unacceptable. We've allowed them to exist alongside us for long enough; this affront will be their final mistake – let's get to battle!

The Asrai - that's Wood Elves to you uneducated lot - 'ave got off the fence led their armies against us in an invasion of our lands, their armies bolstered by tree-spirits, whatever they are. This move will be their undoing, however, as the rot of death seeps into their wooden allies we'll seek their destruction! Prepare for battle!

The Lizardmen have raised an army - no doubt what's on their minds is mashin' us up into a pulp. I know, I know - like they 'ave a hope, especially with Stromfels and Manann at our backs. I saw we attack now before they're good an' ready.

If you tired of the Norscans, chances are you're tired of killin' - they've raised something of a force, intendin' to go to war on behalf of the Dark Gods'. I think we need to slay 'em all before they can march forth and cause problems for us.
A horde of dirty, stinkin' ratmen 'ave been seen up 'ere on the surface, where they 'ave no right to be. I think we need to get raisin' and bindin' an' then deal with these pests, without delay!

Never takin' no for an answer, the Tomb Kings 'ave raised an army an' surely plan to attack us. Under the circumstances, I think it would be best that we meet 'em in battle an' crush 'em before they've even begun to march!

The Vampires of this land 'ave raised an army and it's looking like they intend to meet with us on the battlefield. This will definitely be their last mistake – let's move to head 'em off an' then slay every last one of 'em with stakes an' garlic an' whatever else we can find, yarrr?

Part of the trouble wiv Wood Elves - 'cos there's several ways they can get on yer nerves - is that you never know where yer truly are with 'em. You can't trust 'em and you can't live with 'em, so the only remainin' option is to kill as many of 'em as you can - preferably all of 'em at once. Let's go!
Now, I know it may not sound particularly piratey to you, but a pact between us *is* required. An alliance will guarantee that our plundering days continue for quite some time yet.

The people of this realm are overburdened with luxuries, the poor beggars! I say we aid these unfortunate mortals an' lighten their loads somewhat. What do yer reckon? Let's raid their roads to free them of their 'eavy burden.

Those swindlin' scallywags - those honourless pirates - 'ave stolen the riches of the land and the poor folk that live there! Its our duty, as good, honest, 'ardworkin' sailors, to take back these treasures and, er, return 'em to their rightful owners. Let's raid, pillage, and plunder, until we've reclaimed every last stolen penny!

The Dark Elves will never achieve their goal to return to Ulthuan if they continue to be distracted by such unnecessary trifles! We need to raid their lands an' take their treasures away - they'll thank us in the long run I'm sure.

That dying race of Dwarfs still 'ave plenty o'treasure down in the vaults of those holds they dare not return to for fear of rats 'n' Orcs 'n' the like. They can’t miss what they don’t know is missing - I say we loot these holds for ourselves!

Apparently, the Empire’s trade routes are - and I quote - "fraught with dangers". I say the mortals who take these roads are asking for trouble! Let's raid these 'em an' punish the merchants who travel them for their truly terrible 'ubris - a terrible thing in any being.

Stromfels an' Manann - gods, I hate the Greenskins, wiv their… green skins an' nasty breath. Some of 'em 'ave the beginnings of an understanding of the value of treasure, but most are more interested in pullin' teeth outta the dead. I call that "poor asset management", and it's not on - let's raid their stashes and punish these gits!

Renowned for their craftsmanship an' the beautiful trinkets they make, the High Elves certainly 'ave abilities. Unfortunately, those abilities don't extend to defeatin' the likes of us - let's take their gold off of 'em and inspect it for ourselves!

Those Lizardmen - an' you've gotta admire they're persistence on this matter - are still pitifully clingin' on to the words of a dead race lost to time. We need to relieve 'em of this burden - take those statues they still obsess over an' teach 'em a lesson!

Norscans are far too uncivilised to understand the true value of the treasure they hoard - clearly, only we appreciate its real worth. Shall we take their trinkets from them, so they learn somethin' about the true nature of the world?

The ratmen have no interest in the beauty of gold and treasure, as they only trade in Warptokens an' backstabbin'. They steal the world's wealth to deny superior races their glory, which is more than a bit of a liberty. Let's take back these riches shall we?

The Nehekarans once understood the value of gold an' built great big monuments to celebrate their wealth. Now, the Tomb Kings just obsess over little jars an' forget 'emselves. If they don't want 'em, we should take their riches away - think of it as de-clutterin' like...

Forever plotting an' schemin' - far more than us - the lords of this 'ere land won’t even notice if we lift a few treasures from under their… well, where their noses used to be anyways. Shall we raid this region while they are distracted? Would make sound commercial sense in my opinion.

I freely admit that I don't understand Wood Elves. The Asrai’s lands are filled with riches, but they spurn 'em and 'ang about in the trees for centuries. It don't make sense, does it? Let's launch a raid against 'em an' take these treasures for ourselves!

There's plenty of dead in the ocean now, all waitin' to be raised for our armies an' crews. Trouble is, we've not got enough chiefs - we need more leaders to control 'em. I think we should summon a new Lord - you agree?
The 'igh seas are just waitin' to be dominated and who better than we to control the waters? I can't think of better candidates anyway - shall we get on out there?

The livin' Bretonnians act against us! It would appear that they're planning to strike at us using this settlement as their base of operations. We need to get over there an' burn it down before they can act.
Our rivals out at sea 'ave taken this land - we can't allow 'em any respite, mind you. We need to burn down their settlements an' take their ships for ourselves - we alone rule the seas!
The Dark Elves 'ave interfered with our plans for too long! Let's destroy this settlement in order to remind 'em that the dead rule the seas… and the coasts… and, er… well everywhere really!

Once again, those pesky, landlubbin' Dwarfs hide in their mountain Holds, hoping to weather the storm that's surely comin' - too stubborn to die, too indecisive to put up an effective fight. This will be their fatal error - destroy this Hold and make it their burial tomb instead!

That phoney god of men, Morr, sends 'is servants to ensure the dead stay restin' an' never rise again. These worshippers must be killed if the dead are to rise to *our* call. It's fitting, then, that we kill 'em an' raise 'em to our service! Let's destroy their base of operations!
The filthy, maraudin' Greenskins occupy this land. We really cannot coexist with such savages as these, can we? Shall we burn down their settlement for 'em, as a bit of a gift, yarrrr?
The tide is rising an' the wind is right, so the time to attack the Asur is nigh. Let's burn down this settlement while the waves are still supportive of our cause?

The Lizardmen have long been a thorn in our side, so we must burn down this land o'theirs - destroy their spawning pools an' raze their fancy temples too. It's almost a shame to be sayin' goodbye to our oldest foes!
More Norscans, gettin' in the way and makin' a nuisance of 'emselves! It'll be noisy and painful for them, but we need to burn their place down now so that we may push forward.

The Skaven 'ave built their city beneath the ruins of our next target. If we just bring these ruins down upon 'em we'll crush our enemy down into their 'oles - it'll be really 'ard, if not impossible, for 'em to come back from somethin' like that!

I tell yer - they're just not interested in all that gold an' wealth anymore. We could get in there, burn down their place and take all these riches for ourselves. There'll barely even notice - trust me!

The Vampires of this land raise the dead for their own purposes, which of course denies us potential crewmembers. Naturally, we can't allow 'em to steal from us, so let's burn down their stronghold an' carry the corpses for ourselves, yarrr?
The terrain here in this woodland impedes our movements. If we destroy the settlement an' spread death's embrace through its roots, they'll never come back at us, not in a million years!

A Mourngul Haunter has strengths which absolutely should not be underestimated - its eternal hunger for flesh can be a great asset to us, remember. However, it's worth notin' that our control over such a beast can never be entirely certain...

Let’s recruit a Vampire Fleet Captain; they aren’t half good at magic an' know a thing or two about ships as well! Just point 'em at the enemy, give 'em a share of the booty and you’ve got yourself a fine new crewmember!
Let's summon a Gunnery Wight shall we? It'll aid our missile units no end - the expertise they've retained from their, er, actual lives, is invaluable to us.
Our melee hordes are so numerous there's no army - livin' or dead - that can match 'em, in my estimation. I say we raise even more - what say you?

Considering they're really quite dead and there's bits droppin' off 'em, the dexterity of our Zombie Horde is second to none. That bein' the case, shall we raise more of 'em an' watch the enemy drown in lead?
Our armies require long-range firepower, just like our ships. We should therefore recruit some artillery to open up a devastating new sea-rout to destruction - yarrr!!
The terrible creatures at our disposal are fearsome in battle - we could make use of 'em an' lay waste to our enemies'… well, everything our enemies 'ave, includin' their lives!

The search for the wreck of the Vengeance is underway and using the map we gained from the shop in Sartosa we have set sail to the shallow seas of the Dragon Spine. However, upon arrival we have spotted a ship flying the flag of The Sunken Land Corsairs. What these pirates are doing at this very location is unknown, it is perhaps a coincidence, but regardless they stand before us and the wreck of the Vengeance; and more importantly the Star-metal Harpoon sunk within her.

Jus’ north o' Norsca thar be a little-known expanse of ocean called the Kraken Sea. It is important to them crackpot Northmen o’ the nearby coastline of Skjold, who drop the remains of their fallen warriors there. T’them, there be great favour to be had bein’ eaten up by those mutated sea-monsters of Chaos, but some of the souls are rejected by the fickle Gods, marooned underwater an’ forsaken ‘til the right juju gets ‘em up an' killin’ again.
column4: The Pearl of the Kraken Sea

column3: The pirate known as Lucky Levi met ‘is end at the ‘ands of ‘is own men after dabblin’ in black magic with 'is lucky rabbit’s foot. The fool was tryin’ to raise Zombie Deckhands for his crew, but ‘is first mate was not best pleased at bein' replaced by the walkin’ dead, an’ so shivved his cap’n while he slept. But Levi’s Undead mob continued to serve their master, throwin’ the first mate an’ the rest of the livin’ crew overboard an’ scuppered Levi’s ship.

Make no mistake, a swarm o’ Fell Bats at sea always ends in blood-soaked waters. As the pirate cap’n Salazar sailed his ship the Salt Lord up the cursed coast of Mousillon, carryin' a single rare Estalian shillin’ swiped from the castle-port o’ Castelo Novo, the blood-suckin’ monsters attacked, killin’ cap’n an' crew in seconds. They say the evil things made their home amongst the rotting corpses an' tattered sails of the driftin’ vessel, but the Salt Lord was ne’er seen by mortal eyes again.

High above Manann's ocean realm, in the place them landlubbers call the Southern Grey Mountains, thar be a place wiv vast seams o’ gold ore known as the Vorgo Crags. None be brave enough to mine ‘em though, ‘cause o’ the coldness an’ the evil things that wander the place… the only piece o’ Vorgo gold known to exist outside the mountains was carried out by the single survivor of a doomed minin’ expedition, the rest of ‘em bein’ taken by slow, painful starvation before the evil mountain Winds made somethin’ unspeakable out of ‘em.

Panteleon was an old Knight o'Quenelles, where those Bretonnian landlubbers are in cahoots with the Elves of the neighbourin’ forest. They say ‘e wore a piece o’Athel Loren amber round ‘is neck - imbued with powers it was, could even bring life to dead flesh! Sadly, 'twas lost when the fool sailed to the Vampire Coast to take on a shoal o' Prometheans… Panteleon slaughtered ‘em, but the crabs eventually dragged ‘im off ‘is ship an' pincered 'im to pieces. But 'is ship, the Lamprey, survived.

Thar be no sailor alive who don’t know the tale of Cap’n Vangheist. A Wizard named Albrechtus von Zeich had paid ‘im in ingots o’ the purest gold to provide passage through the Sea o’Chaos, but when von Zeich refused the cap’n’s ambitions to get the secrets of immortality from the Realm o’Chaos itself, he got shot. Sailin’ on right out o’ the mortal plane, Vangheist an’ ‘is crew left their bodies an’ material things behind, includin’ the ship’s cursed cargo - its fate remains unknown...

The magic that took ol’ Nyklaus von Carstein out o’ Sylvania needed more than just some powerful juju an’ a titanic will… some magic trinkets were also used to bolster ‘is energies, one bein’ the mysterious Stone o’Schwartzhafen. They say it contains the souls of the great fallen warriors o’Sylvania from afore the von Carsteins’ time. Alas, the stone got lost after the Bloody Reaver had an ‘ole ripped in ‘er hull by the Heldenhammer's broadside, tragically spillin’ some booty into the sea.

Reik-Admiral Houghhoff possesses one of the three verses of the fabled Lost Sea Shanty, and by exceeding his infamy you have provoked his ire. He is now sailing the seas, determined to hunt you down and reclaim his place. You must put an end to this pirate once and for all, and in doing so take the verse from him!

Fhiron Wavemaker possesses one of the three verses of the fabled Lost Sea Shanty, and by exceeding his infamy you have provoked his ire. He is now sailing the seas, determined to hunt you down and reclaim his place. You must put an end to this pirate once and for all, and in doing so take the verse from him!

Barron von Heastie possesses one of the three verses of the fabled Lost Sea Shanty, and by exceeding his infamy you have provoked his ire. He is now sailing the seas, determined to hunt you down and reclaim his place. You must put an end to this pirate once and for all, and in doing so take the verse from him!

The fleet grows and the curs of this world learn to fear your name, but there are still those who oppose us. Send these fools to the depths - the Maelstrom will chew them up and spit them out with a more favourable disposition, my lord.
A Lord from Caledor has travelled into the Galleon’s Graveyard! This Asur must be punished for such an affront to the masters of the sea. Assemble the Dreadfleet and sail to battle!

Aranessa has received Manann’s favour before, but this time he has granted her the ability to control the ocean’s dead to bolster her crew. Manann also gives her a task, for there are others who plunder the seas for riches who cannot be suffered to exist in his realm. Aranessa must uphold her reputation as the most feared sea raider in Sartosa and go on a campaign of despoilment in her father’s name!

Aranessa continues to build her strength, seeking out her father’s foes with merciless zeal. If she is to succeed in her task, however, she must show the world that she is building her own empire, with Sartosa at its centre – a pirate empire. As Captain Saltspite leads her crew on further incursions, her strength and empire will grow, preparing her for Manann’s even tougher enemies to come.

Manann’s will can only be fulfilled if Aranessa is strong enough to take down the Sea-God’s enemies, however formidable they may be. She must strike out in all directions at foreign powers across the shores, not just to build up her strength, but also to sharpen her skills as a swashbuckling commander ...and not to mention, to fill the Swordfysh’s holds with treasure!

Once just a den for thieves and pirates, Sartosa is now the jewel of an empire run by Undead cutthroats. Taking treasure from your enemy may be filled with adventure and swashbuckling, but taking a share of every plunder on the high seas is much more profitable. Aranessa’s wealth now knows no bounds, and the time to crush Manann’s greatest enemies is nigh. With power and wealth at her disposal, she is prepared to face any foe!

The Queen of Tides has been the weapon of choice for the Sea-God Manann for some time now; he needs only to point her at a target and watch as his daughter burns it to the ground. None can challenge the Pirate Queen – not in strength, wealth or skill!
column4: Chapter V: Swept Beneath Queen of Tides

column3: From the depths of the ocean she has returned – not even death can keep Cylostra from a performance for the Phoenix King. Despairing from a prestigious music career cut short, the phantasmal diva first expands her Undead crew, bringing her deathly serenades to the hovels of the living. If they will not listen willingly, her deckhands will ensure they do!
column4: Chapter I: Deathly Songs of Anguish

column3: Cylostra grows in strength, but needs more practice to fine-tune her upcoming performance for the Asur royalty. More live audiences are required, though they will not survive the show, instead being made to serve their new mistress in death.

Cylostra’s grip on the world of the living grows, each battle bringing new ‘fans’ and new territory. Her talent is finally being appreciated, so much so in fact that her fame has even spread as far as Ulthuan once again! As before, the Asur are sure to invite her to perform any day now. If not, Cylostra will just have to invite herself, but not before a good deal more practice!

As her power grows and her borders expand, Cylostra can wait no longer to perform for the Phoenix King, as she was tasked to all those years ago. No longer constrained by mortal bonds, she can now reach new heights of fame. All will be made to hear her songs, all will be made to praise her otherworldly talent!

Cylostra's voice reverberates across the open sea, carrying a power in her song that no mortal could. There are none who can withstand her song and live; all who hear it are paralysed, leaving them vulnerable to her cutthroat crew. To perform for the Phoenix King was once Cylostra's goal, but such petty aims no longer trouble the prima donna of Shyish. In her ultimate grace, she has vowed to put on performances for ALL mortals, so that they can join her ever-growing group of 'died'-hard fans.
column4: Chapter V: Dying for an Encore

column3: Luthor Harkon has been battling with himself for some time, his fractured mind recently causing him to lose grip on his Undead pirate empire. Mutineers have emerged, insolently stealing part of his land named for his exploits. The fog of his mind lifts just enough for Luthor to unite his wills – it is time for the Pirate King to raid the hovels of any nearby landlubbers, murdering all before him on his way to regaining supremacy.
column4: Chapter I: The Wrath of the Pirate King

column3: Harkon has re-established some control over both his mind and his lands; now, the time has come to use this momentum to try and repair his psyche once and for all. His pirate kingdom has made great strides, but there will be no lull in the killing. Now is the time to lash out across his borders, especially at the Lizardmen of the New World who gave him this cursed affliction of the mind.

The Vampire Coast grows, and so does the horde of Undead sailors who fell victim to its perilous shores. Yet Luthor’s personalities still bicker over his goals, with some wanting to restore his mind and destroy the Slann responsible for breaking it, while others simply lusting after territory and plunder. Luthor can only try and steer himself towards the Lizardmen, but beyond the Vampire Coast there are plenty of other targets out there.

His mind may not be fully healed yet, but his psyche has become slightly more controllable, his strength at levels never achieved before, and his ambition only growing with every victory. Once Harkon was naive, looting powerful relics and treasures, playing lord of a small land, but no more. He has seen his true potential, petty baubles and faux empires interest him no more – only complete dominance of the world will do.
column4: Chapter IV: The Arch Grand Commodore Returns

column3: The civilisations of Lustria have fallen and those who still draw breath there know their demise is imminent – desperate last stands are all that remain for them now. Harkon has conquered this land intending to create an empire worthy of his power; an empire with borders not limited to the New World. The rest of the world must now contend with the Lord of Lustria, monstrous monarch of the Vampire Coast, the Arch Grand Commodore of death itself!

For many years, Heinrich wandered the Grey Mountains as little better than a half-sane beggar. But that was long ago - since then, the Lichemaster has grown in infamy. Still, these mountains hold a special place in the his black heart, for it was here that he uncovered Krell and struck a dark bargain. As such, surely he has a right to claim these highlands as his property?

A promising start… darkness grows and the dead walk across the mountain chain. The Forces of Order are troubled not just by Vampires in Sylvania, but by the darkness that now shrouds the peaks of the Grey Mountains. But Kemmler's nascent realm must continue to fester or else the mortals will fight back, and all the Lichemaster's work will be undone.
column4: Chapter II: The Lair of the Barrows

column3: The Lichemaster's realm continues to grow. The living flee in terror as well they should, yet Kemmler's power is still to reach its full potential. His fledgling empire remains exposed, so expansion must continue to ensure it can withstand an attack, for it is not just the nations of man who plot his demise.
column4: Chapter III: Realm of the Lichemaster

column3: The needs of the living are irrelevant. Even the Vampires still require 'cattle' to feed, but not the Lichemaster; there are already enough dead in the world, and it is time for the world's greatest Necromancer to harness that power. All shall bow before Heinrich Kemmler; all shall serve in his Undying empire!

The Lichemaster has scarred the world and now his destiny is all but complete. Yet Nagash's legacy remains inescapable; to eclipse the greatest of all Necromancers, Kemmler must scour or occupy the realm, ensuring his empire lasts for centuries. Only then will he be mentioned in the same reverent breath as Nagash.

Lokhir Fellheart has domineered the seas for so long that he can barely picture his homeland far to the north, the frozen lands of Naggaroth. He must eventually return to Karond Kar before the other noble houses make a move against his family in his absence, but knows that he must first expand his holdings overseas lest he look weak when he arrives.

Most inhabitants of the cities despoiled by the Krakenlord in Lustria and beyond have unsurprisingly taken to resisting his demands of subservience. Lokhir's power may be in the ascendancy, but it still remains too risky for him to return to Naggaroth without a sufficiently elevated reputation, which will surely come with taking more swathes of territory abroad.

With ample spoils secured and countless natives put to the sword, Lokhir is almost ready to make the journey home. His Black Ark fleet awaits his command to set sail, but further lands still await annexation. Karond Kar must be made to quake with the news of his exploits – the nobles will soon be reminded that as long as Lokhir lives, none are to interfere with his family, lest they forfeit their necks to his red blades!
column4: Chapter III: Ark of the Krakenlord

column3: Few powerful Druchii can avoid being a target for assassination or deposition at some point in their lives, but Lokhir is one of the few due to his brutal handling of mutineers and plotters in the past. His return home had been hailed as soon as he’d left Karond Kar, and most miscreants who sought to take advantage of his departure quickly thought twice before making a move against his family. Lokhir’s continued expansion overseas shall serve to reinforce that!
column4: Chapter IV: A Most Fell Heart

column3: Only a fool would dare challenge Lokhir Fellheart! With his power and notoriety now ensuring his family’s name is sufficiently feared, Lokhir can concentrate on plundering and slaughtering to glut the bloodthirst of his red blades. Those who thought themselves safe from his reach should think again, for the Krakenlord has returned, his attentions undivided, and he is as ferocious and cruel as ever!

After great effort, Count Noctilus has freed himself from the cage of Sylvania, leaving behind the threat of the Empire and of betrayal from lesser Vampires. The success of his translocation ritual has allowed him to grow an army unthinkable on land and an eldritch fleet of insurmountable strength. Striking out from the Galleon's Graveyard, the horrible creature of the night can finally set about building the foundations of his new empire.
column4: Chapter I: It Came from the Sea

column3: Noctilus continues to grow in strength, his repute spreading faster than even he predicted. To bring death eternal to the entire world, he must bring the fight to more cities and ports, searching out potential rivals and eliminating them before they get the chance to challenge his strength.

The sea swells with the dead and the shipwrecks that dragged them down to their deaths, corpses and splintered hulls sucked into the Galleon's Graveyard, where Count Noctilus harvests their cadavers. Soon there will be none who can rival him in strength or numbers, as his empire of the damned begins to take shape.

The time has come; the dead have dominated the seas and coasts for long enough. The assault of the mainland shall begin in earnest. The eternal night will soon be upon us. None can rival Count Noctilus in strength now. It is but a matter of time!
column4: Chapter IV: The Rise of the Dreadfleet

column3: The veil of death covers the skies; the living are but cattle for the seaborne creature of the night known as Count Noctilus. None can challenge him now, for he is beyond the reach of mortals – once a Necromantic pirate biding his time upon the seas; now the Lord of Death itself. None have achieved such heights since Nagash himself, but the mission is not yet accomplished. All must bow in servitude before the last of the dead rest!

The strength of Krakens' Bane was waning, the Seafather's blessings weakening! The rumours were that a band of Norscan raiders had declared war upon Manann himself in the name of their Chaos Gods, slaughtering innocent creatures of the sea, so Aranessa immediately called upon her crew to set sail for Norsca, swearing that they would pay for their villainy! 

After burning several Norscan villages to the ground, Aranessa found the information she sought, with the help of an Empire captain named Kolt Ludenhof. The raiding parties had originated from the Norscan coastal town of Skjold, whose marauders were targeting islands in the neighbouring seas, slaughtering all marine creatures they encountered and offering them as sacrifices to their Dark Gods. They were under orders from their chieftain, who claimed that the Queen of Tides must be his daughter, who he’d thought dead and lost. The truth is that he threw Aranessa into the ocean as a baby, believing she would attract the ire of the Dark Gods due to the mutations of the sea she bore, which among the Norscans are considered to be a curse. The Skjold chieftain mobilised his fleet as soon as he learned that Aranessa was still alive, believing that by murdering as many sea creatures as possible, he could prove beyond doubt his rejection of Aranessa before the Gods.

Captain Saltspite is no longer a baby to be thrown away, however – she is the Queen of Tides, favoured by Manann, who will ensure the Sea-God has his revenge!

Luthor Harkon had been looking for a way to restore his connection to the Winds of Magic for decades. Many years ago, he disturbed an ancient chamber sealed with some powerful glyphs, resulting in his mind being shattered into a dozen different facets which left him teetering on the brink of insanity. Luthor thought it likely that the glyphs were of Slann origin, concluding that the best chance he had to undo his impairments was to find powerful artefacts from the same source.
\The Slann – a powerful species of Lizardmen with an unparalleled mastery over the Sorcerous arts – are known to use many enchanted totems and trinkets of gold to serve their indecipherable purposes. The best chance of finding one was to search the most ancient ruins of the long-abandoned cities and towns of Lustria and beyond, where the Slann were most likely to have left their mark. After searching countless ruins, Luthor and his pirate horde came across a shackled slave claiming to have been a former soldier of the Empire. He told Luthor that he had recently been part of an expeditionary force that found a chest of embossed Slann Gold, but on their way back to camp they were ambushed by a vast Lizardmen army, the largest he had ever seen. The soldier narrowly escaped with his life, but everyone in his troop was slaughtered and the Lizardmen made off back to Lustria with their gold.

Clearly this hoard is of great importance to the Lizardmen for them to have brought such a force to take it back – there must be more to this gold than its monetary value alone. Luthor can see his goal clearly now, his mind yearning to be repaired. He needs to gather his minions, return to Lustria, and attack these cold-blooded freaks!

Having put together a crew of unspeakable horrors, Count Noctilus decided to ensure his supremacy over the seas stayed unsurpassed, and that the Galleon’s Graveyard remains out of the reach of rival Necromancers also hoping to harness the boundless power emanating from the Maelstrom. Very few can find it without possessing very specific navigational knowledge, but one particular enchanted instrument makes it possible for even a novice to do so – Captain Roth’s Moondial. 

Captain Roth was known for being Noctilus’ one-time arch-rival, after one of Noctilus’ midnight raids led to the demise of Roth’s entire family. This led the anguished captain to lead a fleet directly to the Galleon’s Graveyard, a navigational feat only made possible with his magical moondial. Neither Noctilus or Roth were defeated outright in the immense sea battle that followed, but both suffered extensive casualties. The horrors Roth’s crew witnessed in the Galleon’s Graveyard pushed many of them to desertion following the battle. During the confusion, his moondial was opportunistically stolen, ensuring that the graveyard could never easily be found again.

Much later, following a boarding action against an Empire trading vessel crossing the Great Ocean, a clue is found – a map, supposedly leading to a treasure chest in which the moondial was last seen. Noctilus examines the map closely, feeling like he is looking at one of his own traps, but nothing was going to get in his way. The map might lead him to the moondial, or perhaps to someone who knows where it is. In any case, Noctilus will crush anyone who opposes him!

Those sanctimonious sops in armour, the Bretonnians, 'ave sent an 'eavily-defended convoy of merchant ships our way. Crow reckons they be heading to Araby, and by their sluggishness I'd say they're carrying a goodly haul by those escorts. Let's strike now an' take their riches for ourselves!

So… it would appear that some enterprising fellows from the New World 'ave decided to risk it all against the elements an' of course ourselves, who surely 'ave nothin' left to lose anyway. It's looking pretty likely that Sartosa is their destination. Though they're well protected, taking their cargo as our prize presents an opportunity we daren't pass up.

A convoy of Dark Elf slave ships are heading back to Slaver's Bay, laden with captives raided from Ulthuan's coasts. We should free them... not for altruistic reasons, you understand, but because of their potential as fresh recruits to go on account with us an' join the crew - drowned, raised 'n' bound, they'll be worth more than a cutter full o'gold sovereigns!

Pah! Northmen! Those stinkin' Norscan raiders 'ave been spotted heading back north of Naggaroth frozen following a successful raid on the coasts of the Empire. This particular tribe are known always to take captives for ransom at a later date, so this is an ample opportunity to fill our ratings.

Bordeleaux is a dukedom with long-standing maritime traditions, the inhabitants of its long coastline having had a strong relationship with the ocean by virtue of drawing much of their livelihood and sustenance from it. But across the oceans of the Old World and beyond, trouble brews. Seaborne bandits ply the straits in their ships of war, preying on those foolish enough to sail unsuitably prepared to defend their cargo from those with no qualms about taking it with deadly force. Sometimes it is not even wealth that the bloodthirsty pirates desire, with many murderous, Undead commanders simply hellbent on acquiring yet more dead bodies to raise into their zombie pirate crews.

The seafaring Bordelens are well-accustomed to having to deal with pirates, which is why Duke Alberic found it unusual that he was recently visited by several nobles from the coastal fiefdoms complaining that entire fishing fleets operating out of their estates had gone missing with increasing frequency. Renowned for his personal courage and astounding self-discipline, the duke refuses to stand by and allow his people’s livelihoods to be put at risk without taking action.

There is no better place for Alberic to begin his expedition to cleanse the oceans than Sartosa, the City of Pirates, which lies to the south on the other side of the Estalian Peninsula. Though the infamous thief-ridden port is thought to currently be under the control of the bloodthirsty sea captain Aranessa Saltspite, Alberic knows that the inherent backstabbing nature of pirates means that any number of belligerent enemies could be encountered there. He therefore scrambles his attendants to prepare for departure. Finally, he has a purpose – this may not be a Grail Quest, but it is still worthy of the aging duke’s attention.

There are thought to have been many Enchantresses through the centuries, and she has certainly gone by many names. And no-one really knows how many ages the current Fay Enchantress, Morgiana, has lived through, but as she travels the land between sacred groves, she draws to her side young children who harbour latent powers inside themselves, most of whom return to serve Bretonnia as Damsels.

It is fabled that one such girl was favoured above all others by the Lady of the Lake. As the story goes, when Morgiana took her from her parents, the child gifted the Fay Enchantress a most resplendent hand mirror, said to have inexplicable magical properties born of the child’s own power. Such was the potency of the artefact that the Enchantress always took it to the battlefield whenever forced into violent confrontation with her foes.

Now, however, the power of Morgiana’s Mirror has waned. Upon communing with the Lady of the Lake, the Fay Enchantress discovers that the mirror’s power is closely tied to the purity of the Bretonnian soil. With the defiling taint of the many belligerent races of the Old World creeping across the land, the Enchantress’ mission is clear. The only way to restore the mirror to its full potency is to ward away all signs of corruption that may fester across the dukedoms.

The Bretonnian warrior Agilulf is well known amongst the dukedom's Knightly classes. Once a great Grail Knight, he successfully embarked on countless chivalrous quests to rid the world of its foulest monsters - thousands were slain by his sword. He was also famous for the glittering armour he wore, which possessed a magical sheen that would blind his enemies in combat, frequently giving him the upper hand. No-one really knows what became of Agilulf or how he met his end, needless to say that he failed to return from his final Knightly quest and was assumed to have been killed. Neither he nor his resplendent armour were ever seen again – until today!\n\nA piece of armour bearing Agilulf’s heraldry is brought before King Louen, recovered by a group of Grail Knights returning from a holy quest. The iconography proves beyond doubt that the armour belonged to a member of Agilulf’s household, but it does not possess the fabled radiance and is surprisingly brittle. Upon consulting with the Fay Enchantress, King Louen discovers both that it is indeed Agilulf’s armour and that its sheen and durability are magically linked, its dullness and fragility an indication that its magical properties have long since waned. The only way to restore Agilulf's armour is to buff and polish until its brilliance returns, firstly by melting it down and then by re-forging it. Such work is no job for a peasant smithy – instead, this requires a master craftsman's hands.

Ikit Claw understands very well that direct confrontation with the Lizardmen is not viable, but wiping those tiresome toads from the face of the world always remains a priority, as the Lizardmen plot the demise of all Skaven with equal vigour. In an effort to weaken them before facing them in battle, he set into motion a plan to corrupt their ‘blessed’ spawning pools. Bringing his multifarious capabilities to bear, Ikit used a Warpstone Tractor Beam of his own design to blast the Chaos Moon, raining down fragments to corrupt not just the Lizardmen’s spawning pools themselves, but also the entire surrounding area. The outrageous scheme would deliver the added bonus of supplying Ikit with bountiful deposits of Warpstone to fuel further experiments back at his Forbidden Workshop.\n\nNo plan survives contact with an enemy, however, not even one formulated by the great Ikit Claw, and certainly not when faced with such an advanced foe as the perfidious Lizardmen. Irritatingly, the ever-watchful Slann Astromancers had spotted the falling Warpstone as Ikit approached so are fully battle-ready, and a Skaven scouting party reports that additional Lizardmen reinforcements are already on their way. Collecting some of the pure, fallen Warpstone from the field, Ikit repairs his deadly Warp-lightning thrower, Storm Daemon, and steels himself for the fray. There’s nothing else for it – he must hold his ground and make use of the chaos caused by the storm to gain advantage on the battlefield.

Right now, all of Ikit Claw’s not inconsiderable intellect is ranged against the hated Lizardmen, against whom, in a rare moment of solidarity, the various Skaven clans have united. He understands very well that direct confrontation with the Lizardmen is not viable, but wiping those tiresome toads from the face of the world has to remain the priority, as Ikit knows the Lizardmen are plotting the demise of all Skaven with equal vigour. He needs to find a way to weaken them before facing them in battle and fancies there will be no better way than corrupting their ‘blessed’ spawning pools. The location of these are of course unknown, but this doesn’t present much of a problem – the Chief Warlock Engineer isn’t above extracting the information he needs from enemy captives himself, when the need arises…

After hours of brutal torture, involving several different nightmarish devices designed to deliver the truth in between bouts of screaming agony, Ikit is just getting into his stride when a location is finally revealed by the unfortunate captive. Turning to his assistants, he draws his claw across his own throat in silent instruction; immediately, they move in to relieve the dying Lizardman of what little remains of his miserable life. There’s no time to waste – Ikit must send a spy to confirm that the spawning pools are indeed where they are supposed to be.

Having confirmed the spawning pools’ location, Ikit Claw moves in for the kill by bringing his multifarious capabilities to bear. Always looking for new ways to bring about the destruction of his enemies, he plans to use a new device to blast the Chaos Moon so fragments rain down and corrupt not just the spawning pools themselves, but also the entire surrounding area. If successful, this scheme will deliver the added bonus of supplying Ikit with almost endless deposits of Warpstone to fuel further experiments back at his Forbidden Workshop. To better achieve his goal, Ikit now decides to construct a Warpstone beam to blast chunks from the Chaos Moon and guide them directly to their target.

No plan survives contact with an enemy, not even one formulated by the great Ikit Claw, and certainly not when faced with such an advanced foe as the perfidious Lizardmen. Irritatingly, the ever-watchful Slann Astromancers must have spotted the blasted Warpstone closing in, for they are fully battle-ready, and a Skaven scouting party reports that additional reinforcements are already on their way. Collecting some of the pure, fallen Warpstone from the field, Ikit repairs his deadly Warp-lightning thrower, Storm Daemon, and steels himself for the fray. There’s nothing else for it – he must hold his ground and make use of the chaos caused by the storm to gain advantage on the battlefield.

Lord Kroak is one of the First Generation of Slann Mage-Priests, and possibly the eldest, making him one of the most powerful active creatures of any race. He has an added advantage, however, in that he is technically dead; Kroak’s mortal body was killed during the Great Catastrophe but his remains were preserved by loyal Skink attendants, enabling him to re-emerge as the first Relic Priest. Due to his death, Kroak’s meditative cycles are significantly longer than those of younger Slann. An elder Slann must be awakened to reveal his last known location as, simply put, no one else is old enough to remember!

Unfortunately, it appears that the Lord Kroak was roused from his slumber far too early; not enough time had passed since his previous awakening, so he remains in a semi-dream state. This has caused some confusion – both for Kroak and for his attendants – although he is able to give a rough indication as to his whereabouts, pinpointing his exact location will require deeper investigation by his loyal attendants.

After a considerable amount of searching high and low right across Lustria, Lord Kroak’s Skink scouts finally locate the overgrown temple-tomb in which the ancient Relic Priest is meditating, as ever, upon the fine details of the Great Plan. However, in their haste it would appear that the scouts were somewhat careless, as they have been followed to Kroak’s location by a force of those insidious ratmen, the Skaven! They plan to destroy him, once and for all, by incinerating his physical remains that anchor him to the world. This must not come to pass – defend Kroak from harm whilst his priests awaken him!

Tehenhauin’s following began as a small but dedicated band, but quickly grew as more and more of the Red Crested Skinks of Chaqua rallied to the hallowed words of the Serpent-God. The plagues of heinous ratmen fanning out above and beneath the jungle floor were proof that the Prophecy was coming true. The Prophet enjoyed many victories over them, and with each pathetic Skaven body slaughtered and crushed, Sotek’s worldly power grew stronger and His following – the Cult of Sotek – grew greater still. Committing wholeheartedly to the Prophecy of Sotek, the Prophet and his apostles rounded up those Skaven not slain in battle and prepared them for ritualistic sacrifice in the Serpent-God’s name. Thousands upon thousands of gibbering, jabbering rat men were dragged to the altars and snake pits, the air filled with their fear-musk mixed with the stench of their foul urine and the sounds of their pathetic whining and begging. Much Skaven blood was spilt in the Serpent-God’s name that day.\n\nNow, with Sotek’s arrival finally at hand, Tehenhauin lays an elaborate trap for the Skaven that he knows still dwell beneath the jungle floors of noble Lustria. If everything goes according to his plan, the remaining Skaven host will be driven back and then herded to Gwakmol Crater, where they would be unable to escape their certain fate. Though the Skaven outnumber the Lizardmen many times over, the Prophet’s ever-growing force is empowered by their leader’s undeniable vigour, and they feel assured of victory despite the seemingly insurmountable odds.

The Plaque of Sotek tells of the Prophecy of the Great Serpent-God, whose blessing wards His chosen servants from harm. Only those who have gained Sotek’s favour are granted a blessing such as this, and attaining that favour involves a rite of passage, even for the bearer of the sacred totem of the Serpent-God, the fabled one true Prophet of Sotek, Tehenhauin. Only by following the Prophecy to the letter, exactly as it appears upon this ancient plaque, can its bearer truly understand and harness its awesome power. Tehenhauin, therefore, knows that it was foretold many aeons hence that his pilgrimage would begin in Chaqua, the legendary City of Gold, currently laid low by the vile Skaven of Clan Pestilens…

As is the case for many a great prophet through the centuries, Tehenhauin’s following began as a small but dedicated band, but quickly grew as more and more of the Red Crested Skinks of Chaqua rallied to the hallowed words of the Serpent-God. Now, it appears that the Prophecy is coming true, for there are plagues of heinous ratmen fanning out above and beneath the jungle floor, indicating that the time of the Serpent-God is finally at hand. Upon hearing his pronouncement, hundreds of Skinks rally to the Prophet of Sotek’s noble call to arms.

The Prophet of Sotek’s following has indeed grown many-fold, for the righteous Lizardmen of Chaqua rallied to his call and to the hallowed word of Sotek himself. At last, the time had come to begin the great migration from Chaqua and take the fight directly to the Skaven’s foul nest-lairs and filthy warrens, for the Serpent-God’s appetite for the right kind of slaughter must be fulfilled before He can return, bringing salvation to the Lizardmen of Lustria.

With each victory, with each pathetic Skaven body slaughtered and crushed, Sotek’s worldly power grows stronger and His following – the Cult of Sotek – grows greater still. Even a great triumph over the ancient enemy such as this, however, cannot sate the rasping thirst of the Serpent-God for the blood and lifeforce of His mortal enemy. Tehenhauin, therefore, commits wholeheartedly to the Prophecy foretold upon the Plaque of Sotek, happily rounding up those Skaven not slain in battle and preparing them for ritualistic sacrifice in the Serpent-God’s name.

With each victory, with each pathetic Skaven body slaughtered and crushed, Sotek’s worldly power grows stronger and His following – the Cult of Sotek – grows greater still. Even a great triumph over the ancient enemy such as this, however, cannot sate the rasping thirst of the Serpent-God for the blood and lifeforce of His mortal enemy. Tehenhauin, therefore, commits wholeheartedly to the Prophecy foretold upon the Plaque of Sotek, happily rounding up those Skaven not slain in battle and preparing them for ritualistic sacrifice in the Serpent-God’s name.

Sacrifices of great importance involve, as you might expect, the ritual killing of thousands upon thousands of gibbering, jabbering rat men, and the air is filled with their fear-musk mixed with the stench of their foul urine and the sounds of their pathetic whining and begging. With the sacrificial victims shackled, anointed and otherwise prepared for their ignominious ends, Tehenhauin is ready for yet another great sacrifice to the Sotek the Serpent-God. Though the venerable Slann will never permit filthy Skaven captives to enter their revered temple-cities, the Prophet’s ritual ceremony will nevertheless go ahead as planned: Skaven blood will be spilt this fine day!
