Now that is fightin’ talk! Wurrzag immediately gathers loyal believers around him to put down this false prophet and prove he is the one and only true voice of da Green Godz!

The false prophet is intimidated by Wurrzag's support, but the crafty little git is not defeated yet. One of his followers is sent to slay Wurrzag, but you don’t get to be Mork and Gork’s best mate if you could be so easily shiv'd! Wurrzag foils the attack with ease but the minion makes a decent run for it before he can be severely slapp’d.\n\nHowever, it turns out the would-be killer was merely a diversion! While the Shaman was dealing with the assassin, his mask - the one with the baleful glare, an important part of his mantle as da Great Green Prophet - is stolen. There can only be one culprit - this infuriating Gobbo with delusions of grandeur. The mask and its thief must be found at all costs!

The false prophet is intimidated by Wurrzag's support, but the crafty little git is not defeated yet. One of his followers is sent to slay Wurrzag, but you don’t get to be Mork and Gork’s best mate if you could be so easily shiv'd! Wurrzag foils the attack with ease but the minion makes a decent run for it before he can be severely slapp’d.\n\nHowever, it turns out the would-be killer was merely a diversion! While the Shaman was dealing with the assassin, his mask - the one with the baleful glare, an important part of his mantle as da Great Green Prophet - is stolen. There can only be one culprit - this infuriating gobbo with delusions of grandeur. The mask and its thief must be found at all costs! This is a difficult task, since the Greenskin tribes have been scattered, yet if Wurrzag can control the swathes of the Badlands, he'll be able to find the mask and set about reassembling the Waaagh!, as after all that is what Gork and Mork put him on this world to do.

The Savage Orc Shaman’s forces rage across the land. But the false prophet has gone to ground, along with Wurrzag's mask. However, Da Great Green Prophet is not out of options just yet; someone knows where the Goblin is hiding and if piety to da 'tru' prophet doesn’t motivate them to talk, then some teef or a few shiny trinkets put in an Orc’s hand should do the job. Of course, there are other ways too, but Wurrzag thinks it best to try the carrot before he gets out the stick or, in his case, the extra pointy stabba!

Wurrzag acts on the information taken from the bribed - and now eaten - Goblin. Yet Wurrzag isn’t some dense Squig - he is kunning, and isn’t going blunder into a trap set by the false prophet. So he sends one of his followers instead. If it isn’t a lure and the information is genuine, Wurrzag will follow with his horde and rain down righteous fists on the lying, conniving mask-stealin’ git!

Wurrzag acts on the information taken from the bribed - and now eaten - Goblin. Yet Wurrzag isn’t some dense Squig - he is kunning, and isn’t going blunder into a trap set by the false prophet. So he sends one of his followers instead. If it isn’t a lure and the information is genuine, Wurrzag will follow with his horde and rain down righteous fists on the lying, conniving mask-stealin’ git!

When the Green Godz call upon their prophet they care not for the Shaman’s availability, whether he’s visiting da dropz, in the middle of a battle or simply prancing around the campfire. When Gork or Mork calls, Wurrzag will fall into a trance that can last minutes, hours, even days!

Wurrzag has fallen into such a trance. Luckily he was nowhere near da drops, but in the midst of chomping on a Snotling when a particularly powerful vision struck. All night, Wurrzag remained silent and still, the half-eaten Snotling frantically trying to prise the Savage Orc’s jaws apart. When the Shaman came to, and finally emptied his mouth with a big gulp, he immediately gathered the tribe and told them of what he had seen. It was a vision of confusing sights - blood and death, ruined Dwarf Halls, a group of smug humie adventurers, and a mountain passage of black rock and fire.

Most Orcs look confused, but Wurrzag is enthused with a sense of purpose. While not entirely sure what that exact purpose is, he is convinced that the lands before the Black Mountains should be taken in Gork's… or Mork’s name.

As Wurrzag’s influence spreads towards the petty fiefs of the Border Princes, the Shaman has another vision. Once more he sees that mountain pass of light and dark, fire and blackness. At its centre stands a Shaman, waving a staff of bone, green energy channelling through the staff, coruscating around the Orc and flooding into the creature’s eyes. Who is this Shaman? A threat or an ally?\n\nAnswers must be sought, but they will not be found on the battlefield or in the razed towns of the humies. Wurrzag needs a special space to commune with his masters and seek further understanding.

The crooked moon appeared in the sky for many nights, its baleful grin seen clearly by the tribe. Is it Gork or Mork’s face in the green moon? Depends which tribe you ask. Some boyz wanted to query Wurrzag about it, but none dare enter his hovel, for to disturb him would surely invite great doom.\n\nDa Prophet finally emerged from his ramshackle hut, pulling away the fetid hide that covered the doorway, revealing himself to the tribe. The Greenskins gathered, keen to hear what da Godz' desire. According to Wurrzag, it is to Blackfire Pass they must go, and the Shaman in the prophet’s vision is, of course, Wurrzag himself, imbued with power from Mork’s breath. The prophet immediately dispatches one of his most trusted disciples to Blackfire Pass, to make sure the humies or the stunties aren’t camping in it to cause Wurrzag bother.

The crooked moon appeared in the sky for many nights, its baleful grin seen clearly by the tribe. Is it Gork or Mork’s face in the green moon? Depends which tribe you ask. Some boyz wanted to query Wurrzag about it, but none dare enter his hovel, for to disturb him would surely invite great doom.\n\nDa Prophet finally emerged from his ramshackle hut, pulling away the fetid hide that covered the doorway, revealing himself to the tribe. The Greenskins gathered, keen to hear what da Godz' desire. According to Wurrzag, it is to Blackfire Pass they must go, and the Shaman in the prophet’s vision is, of course, Wurrzag himself, imbued with power from Mork’s breath. The prophet immediately dispatches one of his most trusted disciples to Blackfire Pass, to make sure the humies or the stunties aren’t camping in it to cause Wurrzag bother.

Wurrzag is fond of his Squiggly Beast, in so much as an Orc can be affectionate towards anything. The beast was once a rival Shaman in the Bone Nose tribe until magical energy arched from Wurrzag’s eyes. The green lightning struck the Shaman and instantly transformed him into the Squiggly Beast that has been his companion ever since. Da Great Green Prophet will often pet it while deep in contemplation, deciphering the visions of the Green Godz, or set the beast on the Snotling herds and watch dispassionately as it happily munches through several swarms.\n\nAnd so when Wurrzag woke from a deep trance to find the Squiggly Beast had gone missing, he was not at all pleased. There was a rage and anger there that even Grimgor could not match. Magical energy flicked across the Savage Orc Shaman’s eyes - the Squiggly Beast had to be found or another member of the tribe would unwittingly become Wurrzag’s new pet!

Wurrzag’s beloved Squiggly Beast remains lost. Those he sent cower before him as he rants about their abject failure and how they displease Gork and Mork. One, while remaining cowed by the Prophet’s anger, does raise the possibility of a lead. During his search he noticed that many Squig herds have also gone missing. Wurrzag dismisses them all with a strong cuff to the head with his staff. However, he does agree that missing Squig herds cannot be a coincidence. He decides to hire some "professionalz" to get to the bottom of this mystery, and who better than those Squig Hoppers who have just lost their Squigs?

Those Night Goblins who were recently robbed of their Squigs wander the land on the trail of their missing mounts. They are gone for a while, but on their return bring news that an especially cunning gobbo had tried to rustle a large herd of Cave Squigs from the Tattered Ear Night Goblins. The rustler was fought off and went to ground at one of two possible locations before he could be caught, hog-tied and brought to Wurrzag.\n\nThis is all the information that Wurrzag requires. He demands that his followers raid the settlements and find his Squiggly Beast, or the git who’s dared to steal ‘im!

Those Night Goblins who were recently robbed of their Squigs wander the land on the trail of their missing mounts. They are gone for a while, but on their return bring news that an especially cunning gobbo had tried to rustle a large herd of Cave Squigs from the Tattered Ear Night Goblins. The rustler was fought off and went to ground at one of two possible locations before he could be caught, hog-tied and brought to Wurrzag.\n\nThis is all the information that Wurrzag requires. He demands that his followers find his Squiggly Beast, or the git who’s dared to steal ‘im!

The rustler is found! The trembling gobbo is bought before Wurrzag whose anger has cooled to a steely need for vengeance. The Goblin speaks, terrified as to what fate the Green Prophet has install for him. It turns out that he works for a Goblin Warboss known as Gashtoof, who has discovered a unique fungus patch that feeds off a chunk of "glowy green rock". Once the mushrooms from this patch are given to the ever-hungry Squigs, they grow in size and become even more vicious!\n\nGashtoof has been sending out minions to capture as many Squigs as possible, so he may range an army of 'soopa-Squigs'! Wurrzag decides to let the Goblin off lightly by merely roasting him alive. He is now ready to face Gashtoof and sends a willing follower out to find the Squig army.

The rustler is found! The trembling gobbo is bought before Wurrzag whose anger has cooled to a steely need for vengeance. The Goblin speaks, terrified as to what fate the Green Prophet has install for him. It turns out that he works for a Goblin Warboss known as Gashtoof, who has discovered a unique fungus patch that feeds off a chunk of "glowy green rock". Once the mushrooms from this patch are given to the ever-hungry Squigs, they grow in size and become even more vicious!\n\nGashtoof has been sending out minions to capture as many Squigs as possible, so he may range an army of 'soopa-Squigs'! Wurrzag decides to let the Goblin off lightly by merely roasting him alive. He is now ready to face Gashtoof and sends a willing follower out to find the Squig army.

Seen as an oath unfulfilled, and a sore point for all Dwarfs, the loss of Karak Eight Peaks was a low point for the Karaz Ankor. Since its fall many Dwarfs have tried, and failed, to reconquer it - Belegar is the latest of these who has dedicated his life to reclaiming this famous Hold. As a direct descendant of the last ruler of Karak Eight peaks, Belegar, and all those in Clan Angrund, consider its occupation their greatest grudge.

The Angrund Clan is beset by tribulation. Far from their Ancestral home, and with little of their former power, they nevertheless cling to hope. Angrund strength endures in Belegar; aided by the spirits of his restless, vengeful Ancestors, and supported by allied Clans, he will see the Dwarfs’ glory restored!

With the Time of Woes a distant memory, the Dwarfs should look to the future and the restoration of the Karaz Ankor. The more territory around and even beyond their traditional mountain homes the Dwarfs can claim, the more the Ancestors will be pleased.

The Dwarf expeditionary forces are a brave and vital element of the Dwarf military - they can roam far and secure Holds in the name of their race's glory. Grudges will be wiped from the Dammaz Kron, and the Dwarfs will once again know their rightful glory!
column4: Chapter III: One Dwarfhold at a Time

column3: The Angrund Clan will know greatness again; Belegar has declared it and his is a fierce and renowned determination. A Dwarf's oath is his honour, and his word his bond. The regions outside of Dawi control must be reclaimed, and made part of their dominion as soon as possible.

Not since Valaya and Grungni strode the mountains have the Dawi been in such a positon. A few more realms taken will see the Karaz Ankor restored to its rightful stature - an empire ruled by those who have committed their all to see it restored, enduring as the mountains themselves. One last push, brave Dawi, one final push...
column4: Chapter V: A Second Golden Age

column3: Skarsnik is the self-styled 'Warlord of the Eight Peaks', sat atop a Dwarf throne, laying waste to all who challenge his dominion. Now he finds himself in the west, with the humies and stunties between him and his mountains. Might as well wreak some havoc on the way back, eh?

If the Greenskins are going to fear Skarsnik - and they should - then he must use his influence and build up a great green horde to launch an invasion and crush all his enemies. The local tribes must fall into line or get a proper bootin'!
column4: Chapter II: Get da Gits in Order

column3: It's time to stop messing around and put the boot in! The Badlands, the World's Edge, the Empire - all of it belongs to the Greenskins! Destroy the trespassers, take their lands and get the Waaagh! started.
column4: Chapter III: Put da Boot In

column3: The momentum shifts as the Orc  realms expand. The Dwarfs quail, the Empire shudders, even the forces of Chaos stutter as the Green Tide rises. Now is the time to bring outlying territories into the clutches of the scheming, devilish Skarsnik.

A Waaagh! is happening! The Orcs gather in great numbers - they must bring as many regions as possible must under the Greenskins' control - such an act will appease Gork and Mork and ensure that Skarsnik's name is revered for all time!

Wurrzag does not call any one place home, yet wherever he decides to roam is his dominion. He inspires otherwise wretched and useless gangs of Greenskins to greatness in all corners of the earth, and charges them with achieving greatness across the Badlands and beyond. Or else.

If the Greenskins are going to fear Wurrzag - and they should - then he must use his influence and build up a great green horde to launch an invasion to crush all enemies in the name of Gork (or Mork). The local tribes must fall into line or get a proper bootin'!
column4: Chapter II: Get da Gits in Order

column3: It's time to stop messing around and put the boot in! The Badlands, the World's Edge, the Empire - all of it belongs to Gork (or Mork)! Destroy the trespassers, take their lands and get the Waaagh! started.
column4: Chapter III: Put da Boot In

column3: The momentum shifts as the Orc  realms expand. The Dwarfs quail, the Empire shudders, even the forces of Chaos stutter as the Green Tide rises. Now is the time to bring outlying territories into the clutches of 'Da Great Green Prophet'.

A Waaagh! is upon us. The Orcs gather in great numbers and so as many regions as possible must be brought under the Greenskins' control - such an act will appease Gork and Mork and ensure that da Great Green Godz are revered for all time!

At the foot of the mountains the Greenskins lurk, a vile blemish on the Peaks the Dwarfs once called home. It seems the grobi have been gathered to see off another foe inhabiting the dark, but upon coming across Belegar's expedition they quickly deploy for battle - keen to munch on Dawi bones! The would-be King of Eight Peaks is not about to suffer defeat this close to his birthright, with the mighty hammer lying just out of reach in the vault beyond!

A throng from Karak Azul is on its way. With them they carry Belegar's shield as a sign of trust, gratitude and alliance. Ironhammer's forces immediately begin preparations for war, sealing the new portals created by the Dawi prisoners to trap the Orc Warboss' mobs within the ruined halls of the Ancestors. With the throng of Karak Azul close, it is time to strike before the Greenskins can slip away unavenged!

The trap is set - the stunties will not know what has hit them! Unleash the beasts, send forth Skarsnik’s hordes! The Goblin Warlord points the way, only then noticing that his reach isn’t quite impressive enough. If only he had something to prod and point with...

With Kruggler already at the battle site, busy preparing Skarsnik's new prodder, the Warlord gathers his horde to go and collect it. Slaughtering a few more stunties on arrival, he pauses for the briefest of thoughts: life is good when you're mean and green!

Turns out, the information was correct. The false prophet has been found, it is time to put an end to this gobbo’s sacrilege, get the mask back and show the git who the real Prophet of the Waaagh! is. Wurrzag’s followers are desperate for bloodshed and to bring the wrath of Mork an' Gork on the actual "pretenda". Best not disappoint them.

If Wurrzag’s army had marched straight through the pass instead of halting in the Border Princes for Mork-knows-how-long while he had a long trance, then who knows what state the southern Empire would be in now? As it is, the time spent loitering allowed the Empire to not only get wind of the oncoming attack, but to prepare a defensive force and trap the Greenskins in Blackfire pass, as they have done countless times throughout history.\n\nWurrzag is unperturbed, even when his spies inform him that a vanguard of the Empire's heroes - fresh from questing in a nearby dungeon - have sworn to bring the Savage Orc Shaman’s head directly to Karl Franz. Wurrzag smiles his most crooked grin, these are the gits from his vision, all that time ago. Once they are dead, his staff of bone will be imbued with Mork’s breath. He knows this; he has already seen it!

The follower finds it surprisingly easy to locate Gashtooth’s army of soopa-Squigs in the Grey Mountains. The Goblin Warlord obviously feels cocky enough to take on the wrath of Gork and Mork’s chosen prophet. The Savage Orc Shaman orders his horde to move on Gashtooth’s forces - he wants his Squiggly Beast back!

My lord, the dukes of Bretonnia have resided under a chivalrous code for many years. Honour this tradition, build upon the great foundations of Gilles le Breton, and lead the Knightly Orders forward, to glory!

My lord, the dukes of Bretonnia have resided under a chivalrous code for many years. Honour this tradition, build upon the great foundations of Gilles le Breton, and lead the Knightly Orders forward, to glory!

My lord, the dukes of Bretonnia have resided under a chivalrous code for many years. Honour this tradition, build upon the great foundations of Gilles le Breton, and lead the Knightly Orders forward, to glory!

Our lands prosper under your chivalrous rule, yet evil still breeds in every corner. Many look to destroy Bretonnia, and their power grows as quickly as our own. Stave off their advances and unite the banners of Bretonnia with your chivalric actions!

Our lands prosper under your chivalrous rule, yet evil still breeds in every corner. Many look to destroy Bretonnia, and their power grows as quickly as our own. Stave off their advances and unite the banners of Bretonnia with your chivalric actions!

Our lands prosper under your chivalrous rule, yet evil still breeds in every corner. Many look to destroy Bretonnia, and their power grows as quickly as our own. Stave off their advances and unite the banners of Bretonnia with your chivalric actions!

Bretonnia flowers in true splendour - tales shall be told of your chivalric deeds for years to come. As our borders expand so our code of chivalry spreads with it. Do not relent, for Bretonnia will be the beacon of light in this ever crumbling world.

Bretonnia flowers in true splendour - tales shall be told of your chivalric deeds for years to come. As our borders expand so our code of chivalry spreads with it. Do not relent, for Bretonnia will be the beacon of light in this ever crumbling world.

Bretonnia flowers in true splendour - tales shall be told of your chivalric deeds for years to come. As our borders expand so our code of chivalry spreads with it. Do not relent, for Bretonnia will be the beacon of light in this ever crumbling world.

Alberic of Bordeleaux has dreamed of a life spent questing, yet when his father died he was thrust unexpectedly into the dukedom and has never been able to relinquish the awesome responsibility bestowed upon him. Yet opportunity has arisen at last in the form of dire tidings; the ancestral tomb of the Bordeleaux dukes has been ransacked and amongst the items stolen is the Trident of Manann, said to be descended from the God of the Sea himself. Although horrified, Alberic is also instilled with an excitement. He knows he must rescue the relic and restore safety to the dukedom, and so must investigate personally...

The first and most obvious place to begin the investigation is the thrice-damned city of Mousillon, and Alberic knows it. The dark and twisted visions within its walls are often linked to murders, kidnappings and other deviations; Alberic's quest must begin with those depraved creatures - he will bring justice and righteous fury to those who conspire against Bordeleaux and Bretonnia.

All that Alberic's agent was able to learn during his time in Mousillon is that the city is as damnable and decrepit as ever. Frustrated by a lack of leads, yet energised by the investigation, Alberic knows precisely what must be done next. The Trident of Manann billows on the flag of Bordeleaux as the duke rallies his forces to war - Mousillon will be taken by force, and any surviving inhabitants will answer to Alberic, or face his blade.

The agent returns having found nothing related to the investigation in Mousillon, and informs Alberic that the quest must move further afield if any answers are to be uncovered. The duke is frustrated by this setback, but the agent attempts to allay his worries with news that something unrelated, yet potentially advantageous, has been found in the caverns beneath the cursed city. Alberic, ever inquisitive and now addicted to the quest, readies his steed and makes haste for Mousillon himself.

Every lead that Alberic pursued having dried up, the duke has no choice but to return to Bordeleaux and begin his investigation anew. The scene of the crime may yet yield a nugget of truth or an actionable link that was missed the first time around. With a grim countenance, yet no less of a determined spirit, Alberic sets out to return to his dukedom, where he is certain he will unlock the mystery of this dark crime...

Although much of the groundwork on the investigation has already been completed, a few locals are induced to offer up some additional information. They cannot be sure these men were the thieves, but several locals report seeing a group of suspicious men boarding a ship bound for Brionne. Alberic is gleeful - finally, a clue! Yet his hopes are summarily dashed; the harbour master reports that the ship never reached Brionne and its whereabouts is now unknown. Although frustrated by failure yet again, the duke is determined to discover where the ship ended up. As such, funds must be raised if a search party is to be launched...

With his lips now loosened, the stranger reveals that he is part of a confederacy of thieves hired to steal the artefacts. Whilst their employer is keen to remain anonymous, no good thief is without his ways… He and his companions have discovered that they were hired by a rogue Knight, one with a grievance against Alberic that he was willing to settle by any means necessary. Alberic has heard of the roaming brigands that plague Estalia, but he had no idea they were so personally committed to his own misfortune. The duke is enraged - they were under his very nose and he had no idea! Well, he shan't be falling foul of them again; forces must be raised, and this scourge put to the sword of justice!

Alberic is encamped in Estalia, and word moves fast across the land that a renegade duke has come to settle a score – someone with a personal grievance against him. The duke had heard of the roaming brigands that plague Estalia, but he had no idea they were so personally committed to his own misfortune! The proverbial gauntlet is thrown harshly to the ground, challenging the 'weak and ineffectual' Alberic to face an army on the field of battle and decide who is the better Knight, once and for all. The duke, naturally, is not prepared to back down. Enraged, he raises a force to put this scourge to the sword of justice!

In her dreams, the Fay Enchantress sees what has been, what is, and what may yet be. She stands upon the coastline and watches as an endless fleet of ships, seething with the servants of Chaos, crashes through the waves towards Bretonnian shores. With the power of her Chalice of Potions, the Enchantress summons forth a storm of unseen enormity upon the approaching fleet. Yet though many of them are sent to calamitous, watery graves, even that cannot stop all the invaders. Still they come, the very sea seeming to boil and froth beneath their prows; an invasion without end, a fight without hope. As they pour from their vessels onto the land, unstoppable, the Ruinous hordes seem intent to rip the very heart from the breast of Bretonnia...\n\nThe Fay Enchantress awakes with a start, a deep fear settling, ice cold, within her. She knows, in this moment, that this was no mere nightmare but a vision - sent by the Lady - of what could be, should her strength be insufficient to stop it. The Enchantress knows what must be done, and knows there is very little time in which to do it.

Through days of ceaseless toil and mind-wearying study, the Enchantress discovers rituals that may yield the answers she seeks, rituals that could make her potions strong enough to stop the Chaos invasion from her vision. Yet as is to be expected, the rituals are by no means simple; the Chalice must be charged by three rituals, all of which must triangulate with it from precise locations. The first point of the ritual lies in Nordland, to the east, far across the marches and into the lands of the Empire of Man. Knowing that time is crucial, and that Chaos grows ever-nearer, she dispatches a faithful servant to Nordland to begin the ritual.

With the first ritual began, a flame of hope is lit for Bretonnia. Yet it is a weak thing, dim and guttering; the Enchantress knows there is much more to be done, and the hour is growing late. Even now, she can feel the dark forces at play, threatening to overpower the world itself. The next ritual location plunges deep into the heart of that darkness - atop the gnarled peaks of the Vanaheim Mountains; the very heart of enemy territory. Yet the Fay Enchantress knows that she cannot relent; the tribes surrounding the mountains must be quashed, and the ritual began in relative safety.

Each second that passes is another interminable tick of the clock, another agonising beat of the Fay Enchantress' heart. She knows she has done all she can do, and that the potion is as strong as it can be. Now all she can do is wait and worry - wait for the dark forces to encroach upon Bretonnia, and worry that she has not done enough.\n\nThey will come from the north, she reasons, they will come for Couronne. She must make ready there.

The dark and prophetic visions that plagued the Fay Enchantress have at last come to pass. Dark clouds gather off the northern shore of Bretonnia, and reports reach Couronne of a fleet, manned by servants of the Ruinous Powers in numbers beyond counting. They are so many, it is as if a great cloak is reaching across the ocean. Panic grips the people, but the Enchantress remains calm.

Upon the shores, she grasps the Chalice of Potions and channels its power in the name of the Lady. The ritual draws power from the swirling and tumultuous Winds of Magic, conjuring a dark and vicious storm. Bolts of lightning arc down at the approaching fleet, dashing them to pieces, whilst winds of enormous magnitude hurl yet more ships away to a watery demise. The spell is beyond anything ever seen before, and far greater than the one in the Enchantress' vision. When it is done, most of the fleet is consigned to oblivion. Yet despite it all, more advance. A sizeable force lands upon Bretonnian shores, still intent on seeing the land burn.

The Enchantress knows what must be done. These remnants must be faced, they must be fought and, finally, they must be utterly crushed.

My lord! The outriders have returned from their reconnaissance with reports of a Greenskin force massing ahead of us. They are encamped on a defensible ridge, and have brought their bizarre artillery to further fortify the position – they appear ready to fight to the last. Further reports seem to indicate that they are bolstered by a great gathering of Warbosses, who seem bent on bringing their full strength to bear against you. It is clear they want the same thing we do – a decisive battle to decide our fates once and for all. We must not relent – their scourge must be wiped from the world!

Our march through the Chaos Wastes have been tough, Sire, but at last our courage seems to have been rewarded. Along the Cliff of Beasts, our scouts return with news that the forces of Ruin have decided to meet us in battle. Led by Archaon the Everchosen, and accompanied by the Prince of Slaneesh, Sigvald the Magnificent, the Chaos army seem ready to offer us a fight for the ages! The skies above, ever ominous during our perilous journey, turn now even more despondent. Thunder rolls across the grizzly clouds, and in the distance, lightning arcs through the deepening sky. The air hisses with static; could this be the moment of our destiny?

A mist rolls down from the mountains covering the lands of Bretonnia. The origin of this dense effluvium is as murky as the mist itself; all the people of Bretonnia know is that what was not there before is there now, obfuscating and obscuring all. Yet more troubling than the mist itself is what lies beyond - the shouting and smashing of the Greenskin hordes haunt the dreams of the peasants, who fear they may be next. The people panic, refusing to leave their homes, lest they be next victims of the slavering, rampaging Orcish host.

The fog has affected all. It has become so thick that the light of the sun cannot pierce it. So it is across the Bretonnian marches; a land of quarrelsome yet bright climate now despairs under the infernal fog, forsaken by the sun. As the light fades from the land, so too does the Sword of Couronne's aura ebb and dim. King Leoncoeur grows concerned and so, sealing the ancestral blade away, endeavours to discover the source and solution to the impenetrable mist.\n\nAll across Bretonnia, dukedoms report that the mist is giving rise to mania; a Greenskin horde rampages there, taking advantage of the murk to smash, pillage and spread destruction across the land. Although it may not be a permanent solution, the king has an immediate duty to protect his people.

As Leoncoeur puts paid to the enemy forces, it becomes apparent that the Greenskins were not a unified fighting force but more of an advance party - a mere rabble, hurtling full-tilt from the fog and the forests ahead of a much larger and better-disciplined host. Driven by curiosity and a desire to see the fog dispersed, the king attempts to investigate. Yet upon entering, he is led by vines and half-hidden pathways back the way he came. No matter how many times he tries, the forest repeatedly turns Leoncoeur away. \n\nConvinced that something dark, devious, and infinitely more menacing is picking its way through the forests of Bretonnia, yet frustrated by failure, the king returns to court. There, his advisors suggest an investigation of Artois - the first dukedom to be shrouded by the fog's appearance. Finding their advice to be worthy, the king prepares a sortie.

As Leoncoeur puts paid to the enemy forces, it becomes apparent they were not a unified fighting force but more of an advance party - a mere rabble, hurtling full-tilt from the fog and the forests ahead of a much larger and better-disciplined host. Driven by curiosity and a desire to see the fog dispersed, the king attempts to investigate the forests. Yet upon entering, he is led by vines and half-hidden pathways back the way he came. No matter how many times he tries, the forest repeatedly turns Leoncoeur away.\n\nConvinced that something dark, devious, and infinitely more menacing is picking its way through the forests of Bretonnia, yet frustrated by failure, the king returns to court. There, his advisors suggest an investigation of Artois - the first dukedom to be shrouded by the fog's appearance, and the first to fall to the filthy green tide lurking beneath. Finding their advice to be worthy, the king prepares a force to retake the dukedom and find his answers!

Artois is deeply affected by the descent of the all-consuming mist, but the people still, somehow, endure, in a display of bold Bretonnian resilience. When pressed for information, the peasants mention something about a nameless, shrouded wanderer spreading rumours of an 'evil fog' approaching just before the self-same miasma descended upon them. At last report, the wanderer was headed in the direction of the Forest of Arden.\n\nLeoncoeur knows that even the hardiest Knight of Bretonnia would be in great peril so close to Athel Loren. This wanderer knows something of the ever-present mist, yet is still in great danger. More to the point, his demise would sever the only lead the king has in this mystery. With great haste, he dispatches an agent to intercept the mysterious man.

The wanderer is discovered, but it is too late to save him from the perils that lay in the mist. The King's agent sends word that he was found on the outskirts of the Arden Forest, battered and bloodied and, ultimately, beyond saving. Yet hope remains; a notebook was found on his desecrated cadaver, which the agent delivered to the King with great urgency.

Upon its battered and weathered pages, it is revealed that the wanderer was an elder Questing Knight, lost to the records of the Bretonnians, whose final pledge was to 'clear the mist of all evil'. Accompanying his final quest is a an intricately-detailed map of the Forest of Arden; at the centre, deep within the woods, he has marked a clearing, labelled only as the 'source of evil', which must be the camp of the Orc Warboss presiding over the destruction.

Leoncoeur has no other leads, and if this Knight is to be believed, the mist's source, and ultimate defeat, lies at the heart of the Forest of Arden. Steeling his courage, the king musters his armies, and prepares to forge ahead into the dense forest to save his realm...

The Champion of the Hound, Vashnaar, has been summoned by his master. Scorned by your allegiance to another, they have sent their best against you. This tainted warrior is here for one reason, and one alone: your defeat. With an unquenchable thirst for battle and an unwavering commitment to obey his masters, he will be no easy Champion to best. The host of followers in his wake is immense too, and they share a thirst for bloodshed with their hallowed example.\n\nYou must overcome this Champion, show his master that your fate is not in his hands, and that no matter who is sent against you the triumph will be yours!

The Champion of the Crow, Ludred, has been summoned by his master. Scorned by your allegiance to another, they have sent their best against you. This tainted warrior is here for one reason, and one alone: your defeat. With an unquenchable thirst for battle and an unwavering commitment to obey his masters, he will be no easy Champion to best. The host of followers in his wake is immense too, and they share a thirst for bloodshed with their hallowed example.\n\nYou must overcome this Champion, show his master that your fate is not in his hands, and that no matter who is sent against you the triumph will be yours!

The Champion of the Serpent, Feytor, has been summoned by his master. Scorned by your allegiance to another, they have sent their best against you. This tainted warrior is here for one reason, and one alone: your defeat. With an unquenchable thirst for battle and an unwavering commitment to obey his masters, he will be no easy Champion to best. The host of followers in his wake is immense too, and they share a thirst for bloodshed with their hallowed example.\n\nYou must overcome this Champion, show his master that your fate is not in his hands, and that no matter who is sent against you the triumph will be yours!

The Champion of the Eagle, Azrik, has been summoned by his master. Scorned by your allegiance to another, they have sent their best against you. This tainted warrior is here for one reason, and one alone: your defeat. With an unquenchable thirst for battle and an unwavering commitment to obey his masters, he will be no easy Champion to best. The host of followers in his wake is immense too, and they share a thirst for bloodshed with their hallowed example.\n\nYou must overcome this Champion, show his master that your fate is not in his hands, and that no matter who is sent against you the triumph will be yours!

With the appearance of giant, winged monsters, Frost-Wyrms are thought to be a type of Chaos-mutated dragon that dwells in the underground passageways of the Old World’s coldest climes. Amongst the northern tribes there are tales of one such monstrous Frost-Wyrm called Frigustrex, Scion of the Cold-Void, that has terrorized the tundra for centuries. Witnesses say that when it comes out of hibernation, it emerges from the ground in a heartbeat to indiscriminately devour all unknowing passers-by who get too close to its territory, located somewhere at the frozen northern end of Troll Country.

Recently, The Tower of Khrakk and the surrounding areas north of Troll Country have been inexplicably blanketed by freakishly bad snow storms. Word also reaches you that entire tribes have disappeared from the region without a trace, reportedly perishing in the extreme weather. This is highly unusual – it is not like the hardy Northmen to succumb to the freezing elements so easily. A more likely explanation is brought to you by a few survivors who managed to escape the storm – they say that it was not the icy weather that swallowed their fellow tribesmen up, but a giant dragonish shadow lurking in the blinding blizzard.

If there is even the slightest chance that the fabled Frigustrex is out of hibernation and on the prowl, then further investigation is warranted. This could end up being a bountiful hunt indeed!
column4: Monster Hunt: Frigustrex, Scion of the Cold-Void

column3: There are few individuals as hardened and adept on the freezing tundra than the bloodthirsty Marauder Hunters. They are used to these climes, and will move swiftly and easily over the icy wastes to help your search. Hire them so that they may be sent out to scout these lands in aid of the hunt!
column4: Monster Hunt: Frigustrex, Scion of the Cold-Void

column3: Although severely lacking in intelligence, Ice Trolls are infinitely more resilient in cold extremes than most creatures, and will be able to move through the icy wastes unscathed. Recruit them into your army so that they may be sent out to scout these lands in aid of the hunt!
column4: Monster Hunt: Frigustrex, Scion of the Cold-Void

column3: Just as you start to think that you are losing the Frost-Wyrm’s trail, the extreme weather around The Tower of Khrakk mysteriously dies down. News then reaches you that the bad weather has now suddenly appeared in the region of Zoishenk, in Kislevite lands to the south. This can be no coincidence – you must make your way into old Troll Country!
column4: Monster Hunt: Frigustrex, Scion of the Cold-Void

column3:
With the appearance of giant, winged monsters, Frost-Wyrms are thought to be a type of Chaos-mutated Dragon that dwells in the underground passageways of the Old World’s coldest climes. Amongst the northern tribes there are tales of one such monstrous Frost-Wyrm called Frigustrex, Scion of the Cold-Void, that has terrorised the tundra for centuries. Witnesses say that when coming out of hibernation it emerges from the ground in a heartbeat to indiscriminately devour anything that gets too close to its territory, located somewhere at the frozen northern end of Troll Country.

Recently, the Tower of Khrakk and the Kislevite lands to the south were inexplicably blanketed by freakishly bad snow storms, with entire tribes disappearing from the region without a trace. Witnesses were saying that it was not the icy weather that swallowed their fellow tribesmen up, but a giant Dragonish shadow lurking in the blinding blizzard.

If there is even the slightest chance that this shadow was the fabled Frigustrex itself, then it is worth investigating further. This could end up being a very bountiful hunt indeed! First you must travel through the Tower of Khrakk and deep into Kislevite lands to find the beast.
column4: Monster Hunt: Frigustrex, Scion of the Cold-Void

column3: The Ruinous Masters have many worshippers across the Old World, amongst which the Beastmen are the most primitive. The influence of Chaos only enhances their bestial aspects, making the already-monstrous beasts larger and even more terrifying than they already are. One such pair of one-eyed abominations of the Beastmen are the gargantuan Cygor brothers known to men as The Salzenmund Soul-Eaters. These grotesque leviathans are not only bigger, stronger, and faster than their ordinary counterparts, but are feared even by Beastmen Bray-Shamans due to their ability to dampen the use of magic for others in their presence. To take on the mighty Soul-Eaters with limited use of magic certainly makes for a challenging hunt, but one which will potentially culminate in an impressive sacrifice to the Gods.\n\nFirst you must find the pair of monsters, who are always found together; a surprisingly difficult task considering their immense size. Being of the Beastmen, the Soul-Eaters dwell deep in the dark forests, navigable via the vast network of Beastpaths known only to the Beastmen themselves. The only way to safely explore them is to recruit some experienced hunters to search the woods thought to harbour Beastmen herds to hopefully find the Cygor brothers you seek as your bounty.

Your hunters send word that they have not been able to find any leads in the forests, but have caught wind of a pair of sieging Cygors terrorizing Middenland, hurling giant boulders that are turning castle walls to rubble. It’s as good a lead as any and surely the soft southerners are not going to last long anyway, so they could do with a plundering. Time to bring some real hunters to the lands of men!

You tear through Middenheim, leaving charred villages and slaughtered townspeople in your wake. Not only is there no sign of the Cygor brothers, but the soft fools of the Empire are surprisingly unknowledgeable about these monsters that are supposedly terrorizing their lands. But not all hope is lost – one of your Shamans comes to you, claiming to have a plan which will lead you to your bounty. He can put this plan into action for you, but only for a handsome price of course. You'll need to fill your coffers!

The Shaman returns and discloses his simple but deviously grim plan. Having communed with various godlings and daemons in his mysterious rituals, he now claims to know the location of the Soul-Eaters. He suggests you march your army to the edge of the Forest of Shadows, taking captive any men you can capture on the way – and keep them alive. This plan sounds like it is getting interesting...

The Ruinous Masters have many worshippers across the Old World, amongst which the Beastmen are the most primitive. The influence of Chaos only enhances their bestial aspects, making the already-monstrous beasts larger and even more terrifying than they already are. One such pair of one-eyed abominations of the Beastmen are the gargantuan Cygor brothers known to men as the Salzenmund Soul-Eaters. These grotesque leviathans are not only bigger, stronger, and faster than their ordinary counterparts, but are feared even by Beastmen Bray-Shamans due to their ability to dampen the use of magic for others in their presence. To take on the mighty Soul-Eaters with limited use of magic certainly makes for a challenging hunt, but one which will potentially culminate in an impressive sacrifice to the Gods. First you must find the pair of monsters, who are always found together; a surprisingly difficult task considering their immense size.\n\nYou have consulted one of your Shamans who has a plan which will lead you to your bounty. Having communed with various godlings and daemons in his mysterious rituals, he claims to know the location of the Soul-Eaters, and suggests you march your army to the edge of the Forest of Shadows, taking captive any men you can capture on the way – and keep them alive. This plan is getting interesting...

Dragon Ogres are living legends of carnage and destruction. Most of what the Norscans know of these god-like beasts of Chaos is from the ancient records kept by their Shamans, which has immortalised them in folklore. Amongst the more ancient tribes there survives tales of one exceptionally strong Dragon Ogre Shaggoth known as Traygard Mountain-Cleaver. His power is thought to be second only to Kholek Suneater himself, with the ability to call upon thousands of thunder bolts to rain down on his victims, striking from unpredictable arcs to maim and destroy on his whim. Traygard is indeed an excellent target for a hunt – to sacrifice such a powerful and ancient monster of Chaos would be seen very favourably by the Gods. However, the monstrous Shaggoth hasn’t been seen in centuries, or at least, nobody has witnessed him and lived to tell the tale in that time. 

News arrives of rumours that Traygard may be active again. A Norscan tribe to the north-east, very close to the Chaos Wastes, has been burnt to the ground with almost their entire enclave of warriors slaughtered in a single night. It is certainly true that many tribes of the north frequently perish at the hands of rival warring tribes, but on the night this tribe fell, it is said that a thunderstorm as bright as day lit up the night sky.

This is certainly worth investigation, but you first need more information, preferably from the survivors who actually witnessed the slaughter. With the majority of the tribe dead, this is easier said than done – the few surviving tribesmen are scattered as nomads throughout the region. The hunt is on.

These slave owners are trying to rip you off and need a lesson in Norscan business practices. Attempted robbery begets robbery – pillage their lands and take ownership of everything they own, including the slave you seek!
Time is short – you are on a hunt, after all. It is not worth engaging in conflict with a trivial merchant. Better to just pay the man’s high price. First you'll need to fill your coffers.

Once the slave is under your ownership, he reveals to you his sorry story. He is, in fact, a former Marauder Champion whose tribe was utterly devastated by the abominable Shaggoth they know was Traygard Mountain-Cleaver. He tells you that he experienced a single blow from the great monster which had caused him to lose his arm, then he was struck by one of the many bolts of lightning falling from the sky, which grazed the side of his head and burnt one of his eyes out of his very skull.\n\nThe legendary beast must exist, for the proof of it stands right there in front of you. But now you must see for yourself. The slave gives you the likely location of where the beast was headed after obliterating his tribe – the Chaos Wastes.

Dragon Ogres are living legends of carnage and destruction. Amongst the more ancient tribes there survives tales of one exceptionally strong Shaggoth known as Traygard Mountain-Cleaver. His power is thought to be second only to Kholek Suneater himself, with the ability to call upon thousands of thunder bolts to rain down on his victims, striking from unpredictable arcs to maim and destroy on his whim. Traygard is indeed an excellent target for a hunt – to sacrifice such a powerful and ancient monster of Chaos would be seen very favourably by the Gods.

Having heard that Traygard may be active again, you travelled to Goromadny Mountains to follow an interesting lead. A slave languishing in a thrall pen there was allegedly mumbling stories about a ruthless and powerful Shaggoth with frightening power who destroyed his former tribe and its stronghold. Although clearly gone insane, the pitiful man had obviously experienced a terrible encounter in battle, missing an eye and an arm. Upon speaking to him yourself, he revealed to you that he is actually a former Marauder Champion whose tribe was utterly devastated by the abominable Shaggoth they know was Traygard Mountain-Cleaver. A single blow from the great monster had caused him to lose his arm, then he was struck by one of the many bolts of lightning falling from the sky, which grazed the side of his head and burnt one of his eyes out.

The legendary beast must exist, for the proof of it stands right there in front of you. But now you must see for yourself. The slave gives you the likely location of where the beast was headed after obliterating his tribe – the Chaos Wastes.

It is no exaggeration that very few things truly scare the Northmen and the other abominable inhabitants of the north – least of all, spiders. However, when they take the form of Venom Queens, gigantic in size and made up for in numbers by their hatchling swarms, most would prefer not to face one. The only real upside of encountering a Venom Queen is that there are rarely more than one in any one place at a time – killing just one is hard enough!\n\nRecently, harrowing stories have started circulating that gigantic Venom Queens are grouping into vast spider swarms in the lands to the south. The most recent spate of appearances have been in the Eastern Badlands, where they have taken over swathes of land, devouring any who come near. To most, this would be terrifying news. But to the hunter, this is a prime opportunity for a worthy sacrifice! Time to get more information.
column4: Monster Hunt: Brood Queens of Karak Azul

column3: As you arrive in the Eastern Badlands, you immediately see that the rumours of the spider infestation are true. The land is blanketed in webs and cocoons, and the surface seems devoid of other life. You have also arrived at a time of conflict between the Dwarfs and the Greenskins, who are currently fighting a bitter subterranean war over the many underground strongholds protecting the lucrative mines in the area. You can hear the faint sound of cannons and warfare emanating from the ground beneath.\n\nYou have no interest in this silly war between the stunties and the grobi! Besides, the men and creatures of the north are not adept at digging and navigating tunnels, preferring to fight out in the open like real men. Fortunately, the Greenskins still have several camps on the surface where it should be possible to obtain more information about the Venom Queen infestation. There won't be time for diplomacy, however!
column4: Monster Hunt: Brood Queens of Karak Azul

column3: While sacking a Greenskin camp, you manage to capture a spineless Goblin attempting to scurry away from the area unseen. The cowardly wretch says he’ll give up some information about the Venom Queen infestation for a little ‘compensation’. But there are cheaper ways to get information out of a greedy Goblin! Taking a full three seconds of a beating before spitting out the information, he reveals that Skarsnik, the self-proclaimed ‘Warlord of Eight Peaks’ had recently discovered this group of larger, poisonous Arachnaroks, and had been trying to herd them for use in his own malevolent schemes. However, he could not control the uncontrollable swarm and it had moved on, thought to have gone underground via a nearby tunnel.\n\nYou need to find the location of this tunnel entrance. To do so, the area around Karak Eight Peaks will need to be turned upside down.
column4: Monster Hunt: Brood Queens of Karak Azul

column3: Recently, harrowing stories had started circulating that gigantic Venom Queens were grouping into vast spider swarms in the lands to the south. The most recent spate of appearances had been in the area around Karak Eight Peaks, where they had taken over swathes of land, devouring all who came near. Your spies tell you that this is undoubtedly the work of Skarsnik, the self-proclaimed ‘Warlord of Eight Peaks’, who had allegedly discovered the group of larger, poisonous Arachnaroks, and had been trying to herd them into the area for use in his own malevolent schemes.\n\nYou care not for some stupid Goblin’s ill-conceived plans, but the news of this bounty can only mean one thing to a Norscan hunter – a prime opportunity for a worthy sacrifice! To find the location of the giant spider cluster, the area around Karak Eight Peaks will need to be turned upside down to find their burrow.
column4: Monster Hunt: Brood Queens of Karak Azul

column3: The Greenskins are famous for having all manner of monstrosities in their despicable ranks, including the lumbering Giants that follow them to insatiably feast in battle. Killing one for sacrifice would bring great prestige and recognition from the Gods, for what can be more impressive than slaying a legendary descendant of the long-forgotten Sky-Titans?\n\nYou have heard of one very belligerent Giant called Blorgar the Mad Titan, who is lumbering around the Grey Mountains being more than just a minor nuisance to the locals there. Setting out to slay the leviathan, you expect that the locals having their lands indiscriminantly flattened will be quite happy to see you, but it matters little. You're not going there to kill it for their sake – the hunt is on!
column4: Monster Hunt: Blorgar the Mad Titan

column3: Arriving in the Grey Mountains you find out that Blorgar is long gone, but the destruction left in his wake is evident. Buildings have been smashed to rubble, crops flattened, and people reduced to ground-smears. Although the Giant's movements are still unknown, the locals tell you of a Bretonnian herb collector who might know where the brute lives. The Bretonnian had allegedly made a fleeting appearance in the Grey Mountains shortly before the Giant arrived, claiming that he’d accidentally stumbled upon the Giant's underground lair while spelunking nearby to gather some cave mushrooms. Knowing that the Giant was approaching, he was gone almost as soon as he’d arrived, fearful of the carnage to come.\n\nYou must now travel to Bretonnia to search for this herb collector. There would also be no harm in indulging in a bit of raiding while you’re there, if not just to keep the troops happy!
column4: Monster Hunt: Blorgar the Mad Titan

column3: The Bretonnian herb collector has the information you need, but you don't trust the backstabbing Gobbos to do any sort of financial deal. A spot of subterfuge, although perhaps cowardly from your perspective, may be needed instead in order for you to obtain the hostage. You must send one of your Heroes to infiltrate their camp and steal the Bretonnian right from under their noses.
column4: Monster Hunt: Blorgar the Mad Titan

column3:
The Greenskins are famous for having all manner of monstrosities in their despicable ranks, including the lumbering Giants that follow them to feast in battle. Having heard of one very belligerent Giant called Blorgar the Mad Titan terrorising the Grey Mountains, you set out to slay the leviathan for a great sacrifice, for what can be more impressive than bringing down a legendary descendant of the long-forgotten Sky-Titans?

Once you’d arrived in the Grey Mountains, however, Blorgar was nowhere to be seen. The only chance of gaining any useful information of the Giant’s whereabouts lay with a Bretonnian herb collector who’d allegedly stumbled upon an underground lair while spelunking nearby. Unfortunately this Bretonnian had been taken hostage by some nasty Goblins on a recent raid. The importance of the information known to him is crucial to complete the hunt, so a Hero was sent into the gobboes' camp to steal him back.

Your servant dumps the hog-tied Bretonnian herb collector at your feet, along with some loot he managed to steal on his way out.
column4: Monster Hunt: Blorgar the Mad Titan

column3: Your messengers tell you that the greedy Goblins are asking for a near-fortune to give the herb collector up. It seems they know he must have some considerable value to you. The thought of just killing them all crosses your mind, but then you would be running the risk of them fleeing, or executing the hostage. You need this man, and you need him alive, so you decide to raise the required funds.
column4: Monster Hunt: Blorgar the Mad Titan

column3: Forest Dragons are truly remarkable creatures, dominating the forests as all dragons dominate their habitats. For most, stepping into the woods to find one to slay is either an act of extreme bravery or hopeless stupidity, such is the fiercely protective nature of the beings who dwell there. To some, the elusive Wood Elves are as dangerous as the unpredictable Beastmen, both of whom may attack unprovoked if you trespass into their woodland territories.\n\nSomewhere in the trees and thickets of Athel Loren lives Radixashen, also known as the Serpent of the World Roots. It is thought to be as ancient as the forest itself, and for that, it is a highly prized bounty for sacrifice. As with all dragons, it will be very difficult to track down and kill. The first thing you must do is to travel to the famous forest of the Wood Elves.
column4: Monster Hunt: Radixashen, Serpent of the Worldroots

column3: You have arrived at the forest and now must plan a way to draw the monster out of its hiding place. Knowing that there are often strong bonds between Forest Dragons and the Glade Lords of the Wood Elves, your next course of action seems clear. If you cause enough damage to the Wood Elves’ dwellings, their monstrous serpentine ally may show up to aid them. Even if it doesn’t, at least you will get the opportunity to pillage the dwellings of those estranged forest people!
column4: Monster Hunt: Radixashen, Serpent of the Worldroots

column3: It seems that Radixashen is not interested in coming to his ally's aid on this occasion. Perhaps it wrongly assumed that they were able enough to repel your attack, but in any case, further despoilment of the forest will be needed to bait the creature. You know that there is a great tree of immense spiritual importance to the forest, located right at its heart. Known as the Oak of Ages, not only is it considered the source of the forest’s power, but is also the annual birthplace of their King in the Woods. Surely, the Serpent of the World Roots cannot ignore the desecration of such a revered and important location. It is time to raise the raiding banners!
column4: Monster Hunt: Radixashen, Serpent of the Worldroots

column3:
Forest Dragons are truly remarkable creatures, dominating the forests as all Dragons dominate their habitats. For most, stepping into the woods to find one to slay is either an act of extreme bravery or hopeless stupidity, such is the fiercely protective nature of the beings who dwell there. To some, the Wood Elves are as dangerous as the unpredictable Beastmen, both of whom may attack unprovoked if you trespass into their woodland territories.

Somewhere in the trees and thickets of Athel Loren lives the Forest Dragon known as Radixashen, Serpent of the Worldroots. It is thought to be as ancient as the forest itself, and for that, it is a highly prized bounty for sacrifice. As with all Dragons, however, it is very elusive. Striding blindly into the forest to find it would be foolish and futile – the best course of action would be to make the beast come to you.

Knowing Radixashen to be one of the great protectors of the Elves’ forest, you can think of one target that will surely draw the Dragon out. The great tree known as the Oak of Ages, which is not only considered the source of the forest’s power, is also the annual birthplace of the Elven King in the Woods. Surely, the Serpent of the Worldroots will not be able to ignore the desecration of such a revered and important location. It is time to raise the raiding banners!
column4: Monster Hunt: Radixashen, Serpent of the Worldroots

column3: Mammoths are important tools of war for the northern tribes, and highly valued for sacrifice to the Dark Gods. Lately there have been sightings of some particularly impressive specimens around Norscan regions, rumoured to be members of a legendary herd of behemoths known as The Great Mawherd of Bloodfjord. This herd is thought to graze on the icy slopes of the Mountains of Hel. These beasts shall be a great offering indeed – go there and seek out this herd for a dark sacrifice!
column4: Monster Hunt: The Great Mawherd of Bloodfjord

column3: Arriving in the mountains of Hel, the elephantine beasts are nowhere to be found. Instead, it seems that there are several Dwarf warriors to the area, namely Slayers and Rangers. Clearly, they too are hunting this herd, but you can’t be sure of their motives. The nearest Dwarfholds are in the nearby Gianthome Mountains – go there and squeeze some information out of them!
column4: Monster Hunt: The Great Mawherd of Bloodfjord

column3: You have gathered information that a large Dwarf expedition has just departed to hunt down the herd. The Dwarfs’ involvement is an interesting development, since they are not known to be avid monster hunters, nor are they known to use mammoths in their battle-ranks as the northern tribes do. There must be good a reason for them to have left the safety of their holds just to hunt down some belligerent beasts. They were last seen marching for Kislev, so some further reconnaissance will be needed.
column4: Monster Hunt: The Great Mawherd of Bloodfjord

column3: Mammoths are important tools of war for the northern tribes, and highly valued for sacrifice to the Dark Gods. Lately there have been sightings of some particularly impressive specimens around Norscan regions, rumoured to be members of a legendary herd of behemoths known as the Great Mawherd of Bloodfjord. They are thought to graze on the icy slopes of the Mountains of Hel.\n\nSetting out to hunt the herd down for yourself, you catch wind that rather unusually for Dwarfs, a throng of Slayers and Rangers had also recently been in the Mountains of Hel to hunt the beasts. The Dwarfs’ involvement is interesting, since they are not known to be avid monster hunters, nor are they known to use mammoths in their battle-ranks as the northern tribes do. There must be good a reason for them to have left the safety of their holds just to hunt down some belligerent beasts. They were last seen marching for Kislev, so some further reconnaissance there is needed.
column4: Monster Hunt: The Great Mawherd of Bloodfjord

column3:
Soaring above the eldritch plains of Sylvania there exists a rare species of gargantuan bat-like monster that is as giant and powerful as the largest of dragons. They are known as Terrorgheists, flying nocturnal beasts of rotten flesh and withered organs exposed to the night air. Although most are guided by the will of their evil masters, some Terrorgheists are more self-serving, drawing their power and evil intent from the very soil of their Undead homeland. It is said that to bring down such a beast takes the greatest of hunters. This sounds like just the kind of sacrifice that would be seen very favourably by the Gods!

There is one ancient Terrorgheist known to be more terrifying than all others, with a scream that is said to break the will of any man, and eyes like black holes that suck in all manner of magical energies and light. It is known as the Abyssal Shrieker, an abominable Terrorgheist spoken about only in nightmarish tales shrouded in myth, the fragments of truth of which are unknown to most.

It would certainly be foolish to enter into this hunt with no knowledge of the bounty, so before setting off to find the monster, you call upon one most likely to have knowledge of the Old World’s ancient beasts – a Shaman-Sorcerer.

Delving into his vast collection of tomes and scrolls, the Shaman reveals that any records which might have mentioned the Abyssal Shrieker were so ancient that they are lost in the streams of time. With no hint as to where the monster’s lair could be, its very existence is in question. At the very least the Shaman is able to tell you that he knows Terrorgheists to be deeply bound to necromancy in the Sylvanian lands, and one particular Sylvanian family is known to be frequently mentioned in some records as having hunted the terrible beasts in the past. It’s not much to go on, but it’s a start. You must search out any remnants of this family in the lands of Sylvania.

After a short stint of raiding around Sylvanian lands, you come across an old manor known to be the former home of the Sylvanian family you seek. The house is lifeless – the line of nobility that used to live there had long ended, leaving only howling ghosts of the past that scatter into the shadows as you arrive. Searching every room, you come across a study with an old skeleton sat at a desk, a quill still in its hand. On the table is a leather-bound notebook containing a written history of the family who once lived there.

According to the notebook, the former inhabitants of the house were once nobles of nearby Stirland, which was frequently haunted by The Abyssal Shrieker. The skeleton sat at the table was, in fact, a former Stirlander Lord, a renowned hunter who had once attempted to kill the exceptionally dangerous centuries-old monster himself. After a vicious battle, the great Lord failed to slay the beast and narrowly escaped with his life. Although he survived the encounter, he paid a terrible price for his defeat. The Terrorgheist absorbed almost all of his life-force and strength to make itself even more powerful, leaving the once-great hunter a sickly, weak individual, an affliction that infected his entire family and bloodline. Withered and disgraced, the noble and his kin exiled themselves to Sylvania where they eventually perished in shame.

Clearly, this pathetic Stirlander was nowhere near as great a hunter as you! He at least managed to record the location of his defeat, which you assume to be in the vicinity of the Abyssal Shrieker’s lair. All that remains to do is travel to Wurtbad to find it.

Soaring above the eldritch plains of Sylvania there exists flying nocturnal beasts of rotten flesh and withered organs exposed to the night air – the gargantuan bat-like monsters known as Terrorgheists. One such beast known as the Abyssal Shrieker is more terrifying than all others,with a scream that is said to break the will of any man, and eyes like black holes that suck in all magical energies and light. It is an abominable creature spoken about only in nightmarish tales shrouded in myth, the fragments of truth of which are unknown to most.

In your hunt for the Abyssal Shrieker you obtained a leather-bound notebook containing a written history of the last individual who had attempted to kill it. This long-dead hunter was once a noble of Stirland, which for a time was frequently haunted by the mysterious centuries-old monster, so he set out to kill it himself. According to the notebook, the great Lord failed to slay the beast after a vicious battle, from which he only narrowly escaped with his life. Although he survived the encounter, he paid a terrible price for his defeat. The Terrorgheist absorbed almost all of his lifeforce and strength to make itself even more powerful, leaving the once-great hunter a sickly, weak individual, an affliction suffered by his entire family and bloodline. Withered and disgraced, the noble and his kin exiled themselves to Sylvania where they all eventually perished in shame.

Clearly, this pathetic Stirlander was nowhere near as great a hunter as you! He at least managed to record the location of his defeat, which you assume to be in the vicinity of the Abyssal Shrieker’s lair. All that remains to do is travel to Wurtbad to find it.

The harsh and desolate wastes of Norsca embrace you into its cold and wintery grip, my Lord, yet it cannot sustain your appetite for war indefinitely. You will need to voyage from this land to raid and pillage, your Gods will gaze favourably upon you for this. Raze in their name and align yourself with one to be granted their twisted and Ruinous gifts.

The harsh and desolate wastes of Norsca embrace you into its cold and wintery grip, my Lord, yet it cannot sustain your appetite for war indefinitely. You will need to voyage from this land to raid and pillage, your Gods will gaze favourably upon you for this. Raze in their name and align yourself with one to be granted their twisted and Ruinous gifts.

Your allegiance grows, my Lord, and can be strengthened further still as you raze further settlements and erect monoliths in their place. Build upon this bond and ascend beneath your God's gaze. The riches of the Old World are at your mercy - feast upon them as you would a suckling pig!

Your allegiance grows, my Lord, and can be strengthened further still as you raze further settlements and erect monoliths in their place. Build upon this bond and ascend beneath your God's gaze. The riches of the Old World are at your mercy - feast upon them as you would a suckling pig!

As you wreak havoc and destruction upon the world, my Lord, your allegiance to your God builds. The Norse Gods are a maleficent group - stray from your master now and you will surely feel its wrath. Give yourself fully, however, and you will become their Champion, marked for all to see by your pure devotion.

As you wreak havoc and destruction upon the world, my Lord, your allegiance to your God builds. The Norse Gods are a maleficent group - stray from your master now and you will surely feel its wrath. Give yourself fully, however, and you will become their Champion, marked for all to see by your pure devotion.

The Hound God sits brooding upon a vast and ornately carved brass throne atop a great mountain of blood-stained bones, observing your progress with disdain. Although impressed by the slaughter – especially your dispatching of the other petty Gods’ Champions – it is insulted that the killing was not done in its name, so sends its own challenger to defeat you…

The ancient Crow God is very established amongst the Norscan tribes, personified as a gigantic and massively bloated creature surrounded by dark clouds of tiny daemonic insects. It is thought to be a ‘generous’ spirit, always interested in the plight of its mortal followers. Now, however, even the Crow’s generosity has worn thin. Observing your defeat of the other petty Gods’ Champions, it is angry that the killing was not done in its name, so is sending a repulsive challenger to deliver punishment...

Those who worship the Serpent God do so for pleasure and personal gain, knowing that it is within its power to imbue followers with a portion of its radiant glory. The allure of the Serpent is highly addictive to most, but you have infuriated it by resisting the lure of its pride, arrogance, and excess. Having observed you obliterate the other petty Gods’ Champions with interest, the Serpent God simultaneously writhes in disgust at your shunning. Now it sends a challenger, as charismatic as all its Champions…

The inconstant Eagle God knows each trivial seed of hate in man’s heart, just as it knows the ultimate fate of every star in the cosmos. Its plans are convoluted and vast, spanning untold aeons, inexplicable and contradictory to mortal minds. Having observed you obliterate the other petty Gods’ Champions with interest, it simultaneously writhes in disgust that you have shunned it, and so has set another one of its plans into motion. The final challenger, the Champion of the Eagle God, awaits you in battle!

Zoishenk is being battered by an extreme blizzard, the likes of which you’d just seen at The Tower of Khrakk. Your scouts tell you that a dragon-like shadow has been spotted up ahead, moving directly into the heart of the blizzard where the weather is at its worse. This can be none other than the Scion of the Cold-Void itself! There is only one way to see this hunt through to its conclusion, and that is to follow the monster right into the eye of the storm. It is time to claim the legendary beast for the Gods!
column4: Monster Hunt: Frigustrex, Scion of the Cold-Void

column3:
You reach the edge of the forest, having taken on dozens of captives on the way. These unfortunates will serve as living bait to lure the Soul-Eaters out, who will likely be accompanied by the vicious Beastman herd they march with. The hostages are chained up and hammered to stakes upside down by their ankles, deliberately drawing their blood. The beasts will surely catch the scent, and it will be hard for them to resist the lure of injured, defenceless prey.

From a safe distance you watch the doomed hostages, as their screams echo between the trees. Out of nowhere, a frighteningly large tide of Beastmen suddenly emerges from the thickets, gorily devouring the victims, ripping them piece from piece, limb from torso. Then, almost as quickly as they’d appeared, they were gone. The scene of carnage and bloodshed is immediately surveyed and two pairs of hoof marks are found amongst the gored bodies, much larger than that of even the largest Cygors ever seen. Your bounty is here!

You give the order to march directly into the dark, uninviting wood, following the enormous tracks. The Forest of Shadows shall give up its prize – the Salzenmund Soul-Eaters will be yours to sacrifice!

Following your lead, your army strides into the wastelands of the far north. The slave was speaking the truth – your scouts report back that the monstrous Traygard has been spotted not far from your location, and if you move immediately you can cut him off at the Cliff of Beasts. At last! Your search may soon be at an end, and the great hunt will finally begin in earnest.

It did not take long for the location of the tunnel entrance to be discovered. There are multiple giant spider tracks leading into the subterranean passageway, making it easy to identify as the one you seek. Being cautious, you send scouts ahead to descend into the tunnel first, who return to tell you that the tunnel leads into an even bigger network of tunnels beneath. The spider tracks are as clear as day and the herd will be found, if only you follow them. All that remains is for you to lead your army down there…
column4: Monster Hunt: Brood Queens of Karak Azul

column3: The Bretonnian herb collector you took so much trouble to find is almost mute with shock due to his experiences, but after some gentle coercing with torture, he reveals to you the location of the Giant’s dwelling. The lair of Blorgar the Mad Titan is located deep in Grey Mountains, in one of the few mushroom caves large enough for him to live in. It is time to march back there and enter the bowels of the earth to hunt the Giant down!
column4: Monster Hunt: Blorgar the Mad Titan

column3: At long last, the dragon has taken your bait! While burning the region around the Oak of Ages to ashes, your scouts report seeing a great Forest Dragon lurking in front of the great tree. It can only be the Serpent of the World Roots itself, coming to the aid of the Oak. The time for raiding is over, Radixashen will be yours!
column4: Monster Hunt: Radixashen, Serpent of the Worldroots

column3: Your scouts inform you that the crazy Dwarfs are in fact hunting the herd to settle an old grudge – revenge for the Mawherd's trampling of one of their past throng leaders. Stranger still, while you have been on the trail of this mighty mammoth herd, you have not seen any actual traces of its presence anywhere. Large herds of such gargantuan beasts are known to indiscriminately trample anything that gets in their way while on their migration routes – vegetation, settlements, people – but you’ve observed limited evidence of such activity. With the Dwarf expedition now heading towards High Pass, it is time to go and witness The Great Mawherd of Bloodfjord for yourself, if indeed it is actually there!
column4: Monster Hunt: The Great Mawherd of Bloodfjord

column3: The scale of the battle fought between the Stirlander Lord and the Abyssal Shrieker must have been immense. At the location of the hunter’s defeat you find swathes of land that once contained villages and vegetation that had been flattened in a massive skirmish, with the ancient remains of people and animals caught up in encounter strewn across the land. Following a trail of bones, you find the Terrorgheist’s lair in a nearby haunted forest – an obvious location for the dwelling of such an evil creature. You will surely succeed where the ‘great’ Stirlander Hunter failed!

Throgg is no ordinary Troll. Although as physically brutish and savage as all other Trolls, his mutations have also gifted him a grim and malevolent cunning, making him widely feared as an ambushing killer of ruthless precision. Proclaiming himself a ‘Lord of all Trolls and Monsters’, the greatest of Heroes regularly ride northwards to attempt to slay him. And every season, the Troll King dines on their flesh.

Having just defeated and devoured his last unfortunate challenger, Throgg stares down at the broken bodies of his half-eaten meals. As he rubs the top of his malformed head he becomes infuriated, remembering that he had been missing his prized Wintertooth Crown for far too long now. It was stolen from right under his nose many moons ago, and Throgg wants it back. It is a powerful and valuable artefact but more importantly, when he finally brings about his plan of a new ice age and enslaves all the races of the world, it will symbolise his position as more than just the Troll King – but as an overlord to all! Throgg decides to head southward to find and reclaim what is rightfully his, intent on killing anything that dares to get in his way. After all, if the realms of civilisation were so keen to fight him and his bestial subjects, then he would happily oblige, with all the monsters of Troll Country at his side!

Before Throgg can start the search for his crown he must order the building of a new Plunder Hall to bestir the raiding desires of his accompanying minions: the stinking beasts, drooling mutants, and tormented madmen who will help him pillage the southern lands as he searches for his crown and fulfils his plans of domination.

At last, the Plunder Hall is complete! Immediately, Throgg feels the stirring of his subjects all across the frozen northern lands and the anticipation of the despoilment to come, all of which was making him salivate with near-crazed excitement. But still, something is missing. The Troll King’s army is still without the most feared of all Troll-kind – the Norscan Ice Trolls, whose foul, icy breath causes all before them to freeze dead in their tracks before being eaten.\n\nWith his army poised to head south, Throgg is unlikely to find any Ice Trolls to recruit once they are on the march.
